posts.creator: David Li
posts.title: Now in Public Preview: GitHub Copilot build performance for Windows
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Last year, we launched our new GitHub Copilot build performance capabilities in Private Preview. With help from our fantastic C++ community, we gathered insights and addressed key feedback. We‚Äôre happy to share that GitHub Copilot build performance for Windows is now in Public Preview. Today, all C++ developers can try out the new capabilities in the latest Visual Studio 2026 Insiders.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve tried the feature for a few hours and I‚Äôm happily impressed. The agent provided accurate suggestions, implemented them, and managed to reduce my build time by about 20%.‚Äù ‚Äì Alessandro Vergani, ARGO Vision
Optimizing Build Times with GitHub Copilot
When you use this new capability in Visual Studio, GitHub Copilot will use an agent to:
Initiate a build and capture a diagnostic trace
Identify bottlenecks in the following areas:

expensive headers
long function generation times
costly template instantiations
Suggest and apply optimizations
Validate changes through rebuilds so your code stays correct
Report measurable improvements and recommend next steps
To see how it works in action, please watch our demo below.

Learn more: Documentation for GitHub Copilot build performance for Windows | Microsoft Learn
Using GitHub Copilot build performance for Windows
There are several ways to start the new build performance capabilities:
1. Select the responder in Copilot Chat by typing ‚Äú@BuildPerfCpp‚Äù

2. Select menu entry Build > Run Build Insights > Improve build performance

3. If you already have a .etl trace file open from Build Insights, click Improve on the top right corner of the report view. The view or tab you click from gives GitHub Copilot important context to focus on the relevant hot spots when the chat session begins.

Once you start a chat session from any of the entry points above, GitHub Copilot begins analyzing your build and offering suggestions to reduce build time. It will iterate on these optimizations until your build completes successfully. You‚Äôll always have final approval on whether to apply the changes.
Using The Build Insights Tool
To start trace collection, GitHub Copilot will ask your permission to run the Build Insights tool.

If it is your first time using Build Insights, you will need to grant a one-time elevated request.
¬†
Learn more: Build Insights needs additional permissions | Microsoft Learn
Template Instantiation Collection
To collect template information, you must opt-in via Tools > Options > Build Insights > Trace Collection > Collect template instantiation.
Default Report Location
By default, your reports will be saved in %TEMP%/BuildInsights. You can customize the save location at Tools > Options > Build Insights > Trace Collection > Override default location for saved reports.
Share your feedback
We‚Äôd love to hear feedback on how we can improve GitHub Copilot build performance for Windows. Please leave feedback by commenting below or report any issues with Help > Send Feedback.
The post Now in Public Preview: GitHub Copilot build performance for Windows appeared first on C++ Team Blog.

posts.creator: Andrey Belyaev
posts.title: Spring Boot Debugging ‚Äì Now Remote
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
We released Spring Debugger in May 2025 to bring more clarity to the ‚Äúmagic‚Äù behind Spring Boot ‚Äì helping you see what‚Äôs really happening inside your running application. By the end of 2025, the plugin had reached more than 300,000 unique downloads and became a trusted tool within the developer community.
We‚Äôve received a lot of valuable feedback, including feature requests, bug reports, and improvement ideas. Surprisingly, this was the most common question:
‚ÄúCan I debug remote applications?‚Äù
In this version, we‚Äôre happy to say that yes, you can.
Remote debug with Spring Debugger
When we started developing Spring Debugger, one of our cornerstone principles was:
‚ÄúWe do not want to use any debug agents.‚Äù
Adding agents to local code often makes setup harder, increases maintenance overhead, and can interfere with the debugging process. We decided to keep this approach for remote debugging as well.
The main challenge in remote debugging was gathering bean information after attaching to the app.
In the local setup, that‚Äôs simple ‚Äì we set a non-suspending breakpoint in the method that finalizes Spring context initialization and then read all beans from the context. Remotely, however, the application is already running, and the context is fully initialized when we attach.
Container threading model and debugging
Our current solution is to suspend one of the servlet-container threads and read the Spring context from that thread. This approach is where our decision to avoid using debug agents is truly tested.
The behavior of Spring Debugger depends on which embedded servlet container your Spring Boot app is using, as each container handles network I/O and worker threads differently.
With Apache Tomcat, the connector maintains a pool of worker threads as soon as the server starts. Because these threads are available and ready before any HTTP request arrives, the Spring Debugger can hook into one of them immediately after startup and fetch the Spring application context.
By contrast, with Eclipse Jetty or Undertow, the thread model is more layered. For example, Jetty uses separate producer (I/O) threads and worker (task) threads submitted to an Executor.¬†
Undertow uses I/O (event‚Äêloop) threads for non‚Äêblocking network handling and dispatches to worker threads for actual request processing.¬†
Because a fully available worker thread with access to the Spring context can only appear once a request is processed, the debugger cannot load context information until the first incoming connection.
In short, when running on Tomcat, Spring Debugger can present the context immediately. When running on Jetty/Undertow, there is a slight delay in context loading before the first HTTP request. This is not a bug ‚Äì it is a design trade-off linked to our agent-free inspection approach.
You can still debug remote Spring applications with nearly all Spring Debugger features ‚Äì the main difference is when the context becomes available for inspection.
How to configure remote debugging
The process is the same as standard JVM remote debugging ‚Äì run your application with an open debug port and connect using the Remote JVM Debug configuration.
For example, in a Docker Compose setup on a remote server:
http-server:
 depends_on:
   - postgresql
 image: 'jb/http-server:latest'
 environment:
   - SPRING_DATASOURCE_URL=jdbc:postgresql://postgresql:5432/db
   - SPRING_DATASOURCE_USERNAME=user
   - SPRING_DATASOURCE_PASSWORD=secret
   - JAVA_TOOL_OPTIONS=-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=*:5005
 ports:
   - '8080:8080'
   - '5005:5005'




The key line is:
JAVA_TOOL_OPTIONS=-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=*:5005




This is a well-known option for enabling remote debugging. It opens port 5005 for debugger connections and exposes it from the container.
To start debugging, create a Remote JVM Debug configuration in IntelliJ IDEA and make sure to specify the correct module classpath.




That‚Äôs it ‚Äì you can now debug the remote application, inspect property values, evaluate bean expressions, and analyze transactions right inside your IDE.
Limitations
Remote debugging differs slightly from local debugging, but there are a few limitations:
Only embedded containers (Tomcat, Jetty, Undertow) are currently supported.
You need to specify the module classpath in your run configuration.
Database connections are shown, but the database structure view is not available.
The last point might be disappointing, but direct access to a remote database is often not technically possible ‚Äì it may be inside a Docker network, a separate environment, or behind a firewall. We‚Äôre working on finding a solution, but this will take some time.
Conclusion
The new version of Spring Debugger takes another step toward application troubleshooting by adding remote attach support. Even if you‚Äôve never tried remote debugging before, you‚Äôll find the process almost identical to local debugging ‚Äì just open a port and connect from IntelliJ IDEA.
No agents, no actuators, just a standard remote port and a regular debug session.
Simply hit Debug and dive into your running application ‚Äì inspect beans, properties, transactions, and use extended expression evaluation capabilities.
We‚Äôre exploring optional agent-based extensions for environments where deeper introspection is worth the trade-off, and we‚Äôd love to hear your feedback.
Happy coding!

posts.creator: Anna Maltseva
posts.title: Codex Is Now Integrated Into JetBrains IDEs
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
OpenAI Codex is now natively integrated into the JetBrains AI chat, giving you another powerful option for tackling real development tasks right inside your IDE.¬†
You can use Codex with a JetBrains AI subscription, your ChatGPT account, or an OpenAI API key ‚Äì all within the same AI —Åhat interface.
See Codex in action in a JetBrains IDE, as Dominik Kundel from OpenAI and Gleb Melnikov from JetBrains walk you through real development tasks:






Get started with Codex in your IDE
Codex is available directly in the AI chat of your JetBrains IDE (starting from v2025.3). Make sure you have the latest version of the AI Assistant plugin. You will find Codex in the agent picker menu and can start using it right away.




If you‚Äôre new to the AI chat, open the JetBrains AI widget in the top-right corner of your IDE, click Let‚Äôs Go, and follow the instructions to install the AI Assistant plugin. You can find a detailed step-by-step guide in the documentation.




Flexible authentication options
There are several different ways you can authenticate Codex inside your JetBrains IDE, which means you can choose the setup that best fits your preferences:
JetBrains AI
Use Codex directly as part of your JetBrains AI subscription.
ChatGPT
Sign in using an existing ChatGPT account.
Bring Your Own Key (BYOK)
Connect to Codex using your own OpenAI API key.




Free access for a limited time
The Codex agent is available for free for a limited time when accessed via JetBrains AI, including the free trial or free tier version. The promotion starts on January 22 and will remain available until your allocated promotional credits have been used up. We reserve the right to cancel the free promotion at any time.




This free offer does not apply when using a ChatGPT account or an OpenAI API key. Other JetBrains AI features continue to consume AI Credits as usual.
When the free period ends, OpenAI‚Äôs Codex agent will continue to be available to you, but any use of it after this point will consume AI Credits. You can track your usage of AI Credits via the JetBrains AI widget.¬†
Working with Codex in JetBrains IDEs
In JetBrains IDEs, you can make Codex your active agent via the AI chat. With Codex, you can delegate real coding tasks from within your IDE and let the agent reason, act, and iterate alongside you. Codex supports various interaction modes, so you can decide how much autonomy to give it ‚Äì from simple question-response permissions to the ability to access your network and run commands autonomously. You can also switch between supported OpenAI models and their reasoning budget directly in the AI chat, making it easy to balance reasoning depth, speed, and cost depending on the task at hand.




Looking ahead
By partnering with leading AI providers like OpenAI and integrating their technologies directly into JetBrains IDEs, we‚Äôre ensuring these tools work where developers already are, in a way that respects their preferences.
We‚Äôd love to hear how you‚Äôre using Codex and what you‚Äôd like to see next. Are there other agents or capabilities you‚Äôd like us to bring into JetBrains IDEs? Let us know and help shape what comes next for JetBrains AI.

posts.title: IntelliJ IDEA 2025.3.2 Is Out!
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
We‚Äôve just released another update for v2025.3.¬†
You can update to this version from inside the IDE, using the¬†Toolbox App, or by using snaps if you are a Ubuntu user. You can also download it from our¬†website.
This version brings the following valuable refinements:¬†¬†
The¬†Terminal¬†tool window no longer flickers when you use CLI tools with synchronized output, such as Claude Code. [IJPL-204106], [IJPL-212577]
Several issues related to credential storage and settings synchronization in remote development have been resolved: [IJPL-229203], [IJPL-227079], [IJPL-225754], [IJPL-170100], [IJPL-229877], [IJPL-229439], [IJPL-229417], [IJPL-227079]
Run configuration handling in the¬†Services¬†tool window has received multiple improvements: [IJPL-220985], [IJPL-218977] [IJPL-223486], [IJPL-220985], [IJPL-227260], [IJPL-229476], [IJPL-229272], [IJPL-220900]




To see the full list of issues addressed in this version, please refer to the¬†release notes.¬†
If you encounter any bugs, please report them using our¬†issue tracker.¬†
Happy developing!

posts.creator: Sasha Ivanova
posts.title: Rider 2026.1 Early Access Program Is Now Open!
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The Early Access Program (EAP) for Rider 2026.1 has just begun, and the first preview build for the upcoming major release is already out.¬†
There are several ways for you to get your hands on the first preview build:
Download and install it from our website.
Get it via the Toolbox App.
Install this snap package from the SnapCraft store if you‚Äôre using a compatible Linux distribution.
Download Rider 2026.1 EAP 1
                                                    
A reminder of what the EAP is all about
The Early Access Program is a long-standing tradition that gives our users early access to the new features we‚Äôre preparing. By participating, you get a first look at what‚Äôs coming and a chance to help shape the final release through your feedback.
EAP builds are free to use, though they may be less stable than the final release versions. You can learn more about the EAP and why you might want to participate here.
And now on to Rider 2026.1 EAP 1 release highlights.
C# language support
For the latest updates to C# support, please check out the ReSharper 2026.1 EAP 1 blog post for ReSharper. 
Azure DevOps integration: Cloning repositories from Rider
If your team uses Azure DevOps, you can now clone repositories directly from Rider using the new bundled Azure DevOps plugin for JetBrains Rider.
To get started, go to File | Open | Get from Version Control from the main menu. From the Clone Repository dialog, select Azure DevOps from the list of version control providers. Rider authenticates using a personal access token (PAT), which you generate in Azure DevOps and then use to sign in from within the IDE. Once authenticated, Rider shows a list of repositories available to you, so you can select and clone them without leaving the IDE.




At this stage, the plugin focuses on the most common and reliable workflow: repository cloning via PAT-based authentication. This approach matches how authentication works for other organization-based Git providers in Rider and avoids frequent reauthentication or token refresh issues.
This is just the beginning of Azure DevOps support in Rider. We plan to expand the integration over time with additional baseline workflows. If you‚Äôre looking for more advanced Azure DevOps functionality today, the community-driven azd plugin is a great complement to the functionality already available in Rider.
NuGet PowerShell commands support in the Package Manager Console
Rider now offers a Package Manager Console (PMC) in preview, bringing NuGet‚Äôs PowerShell-based workflow into the IDE.
The new console supports standard NuGet PowerShell commands, as well as commands provided by NuGet packages themselves. Entity Framework Core PowerShell commands such as Add-Migration, Update-Database, and Scaffold-DbContext are fully supported, enabling familiar EF Core workflows without leaving Rider. Broader command coverage will continue to expand based on user feedback.
You can access the PMC in two places:
As a dedicated tab in the NuGet tool window





As a predefined session in the Terminal tool window





Both options let you run the same commands, but differ slightly in how context is handled. In the NuGet tool window, you can select the package source and default project using UI controls. In the terminal-based console, this context is shown as part of the PowerShell prompt and can be changed using PowerShell commands.
This preview is about finding the right balance between flexibility and convenience for our users. Your feedback will help us decide which experience to refine and carry forward into the final release. Please share your feedback in the comments under this ticket or in the comment section below this post.
.NET mixed-mode debugging on Windows
Rider 2026.1 introduces mixed-mode debugging, which lets you debug both managed (.NET and .NET Framework) and native (C/C++) code in a single debugging session.
This is particularly useful for applications that cross managed-native boundaries, such as .NET code calling into native libraries or game engines and tools built from a mix of managed and native components.




You can start a mixed-mode debugging session in two ways:
Open your run configuration and enable the Use mixed mode debug checkbox. When you start debugging, Rider will attach both the .NET and native debuggers automatically.
Open Run | Attach to Process, select a running process, and choose Attach with .NET and Native Debuggers. This attaches both debuggers to the same process, allowing you to step across managed and native code without having to restart the application.
Please note that .NET mixed-mode debugging is currently available only on Windows. Please leave your feedback on this ticket.
The ability to inspect .NET assembly output
Rider now offers a .NET Disassembler via a custom plugin that lets you inspect the native disassembly generated for your C# code directly in the IDE.
You can view the native disassembly generated from your C# code, along with output from the JIT, ReadyToRun, and NativeAOT compilers in the ASM Viewer tool window, which is available through the new plugin. This makes the feature particularly useful when working on performance-sensitive code, low-level optimizations, SIMD-heavy paths, or when validating how code changes affect the final machine instructions.




The .NET Disassembler is designed for use during development. You can open it directly from your C# code and inspect the generated assembly side by side with the source. Rider also supports:
Configurable compiler options such as tiered compilation and PGO.
Snapshots and diff views to compare assembly output before and after code changes.
Syntax highlighting for x86/x64 and ARM64 assembly.
The introduction of this plugin is our answer to long-standing requests from developers who need visibility beyond IL and want to understand what actually runs on the CPU, without repeatedly rebuilding projects or switching to external tools.
Enhanced integration with the Godot Editor
This release introduces a Godot Editor addon that enhances the way Rider works with Godot Engine projects.
When you enable the JetBrains Rider External Editor addon in the Godot Editor, it automatically detects your installed Rider versions and configures Godot to work with Rider as the external IDE. It also applies a set of recommended editor settings to optimize your workflow ‚Äì helping with project opening, file navigation, and debugging.
Combined with Rider‚Äôs Godot Support plugin (now bundled with the IDE), this enables:
Automatic Godot project discovery in Rider.
Generation of run/debug configurations for Godot scenes.
Code insight and navigation for both GDScript and C#.
Integrated debugging with scene variables and node context.





Inspect the¬†sources¬†of the addon to see how GDExtension can be developed in JetBrains Rider at any OS.
Search for ‚ÄúJetBrains Rider Integration‚Äù on the AssetLib inside GodotEditor to get started.
Improved Natvis expression evaluation
C++ debugging in Rider now uses a new standalone parser and evaluator for Natvis expressions. This improves the reliability and correctness of expression evaluation, including conditional breakpoints and custom visualizers, without relying on Clang or JIT compilation.
C++ naming rules improvements
Rider now offers a more flexible C++ naming rules configuration. The updated settings page lets you edit naming rules [RIDER-121211], apply predefined naming styles [RIDER-132026], and define abbreviations [RIDER-52334], making it easier to align code style with your team‚Äôs conventions.
For the full list of changes included in this build, please see our issue tracker.
We encourage you to download the EAP build, give these new features a try, and share your feedback. The Early Access Program is a collaborative effort, and your input plays a vital role in making Rider the best it can be.
Download Rider 2026.1 EAP 1
                                                    
Thank you for being part of our EAP community, and we look forward to hearing what you think!

posts.creator: Dmitrii Korovin
posts.title: The ROI of Developer Experience: How a Better CI/CD Tool Pays for Itself
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
This article was brought to you by Cameron Pavey, draft.dev.
Developer experience (DevEx) directly correlates with engineering performance, which in turn drives competitive advantage.¬†
And yet many software engineering teams continue to operate on legacy CI/CD platforms that create unnecessary friction, burn developer hours, and ultimately limit business growth.
While some teams remain trapped by outdated infrastructure, others benefit from modern toolchains that drive measurable performance improvements. Organizations that use performant CI/CD platforms achieve deployment frequencies that are measured in hours rather than weeks, lead times shortened by orders of magnitude, and change failure rates that preserve both customer trust and developer confidence.
This article explains why partial and incremental fixes to legacy systems consistently fail and how modern, developer-centric platforms like TeamCity reclaim developer productivity and deliver a measurable return on investment (ROI).
The drag of legacy CI/CD on business performance
Legacy CI/CD platforms, such as aging installations of the once-ubiquitous Jenkins, and fragmented toolchains create systematic inefficiencies that compound across every aspect of software delivery. These systems weren‚Äôt designed for the velocity and complexity that modern development demands.¬†
Yet organizations continue operating them, often falling prey to the sunk cost fallacy, where past investments in these platforms feel too significant to abandon despite the ongoing toll on efficiency and developer productivity.
Fragmented CI/CD environments require significant engineering attention that could otherwise focus on product development. A typical legacy setup might involve Jenkins for builds, separate tools for testing, manual deployment orchestration, and disconnected monitoring systems. Each extra tool and integration introduces potential points of failure and requires specialized knowledge to maintain.
Consider the developer experience: A single pipeline failure can require understanding YAML syntax, shell scripting, plugin compatibility, and infrastructure state. Developers spend hours debugging build environments instead of shipping features. Engineering teams report as much as 20 percent of weekly time lost to inefficiencies, technical debt, maintenance, and tooling issues rather than product work.
This productivity drain can be quantified. The DORA research exposes exactly how legacy platforms hinder performance. Organizations using outdated CI/CD typically demonstrate:
Deployment frequency: monthly or quarterly releases instead of multiple daily deployments
Lead time for changes: weeks from commit to production instead of hours
Change failure rate: 15‚Äì45 percent, while elite performers are at 0‚Äì15 percent
Mean time to recovery: hours or days instead of less than one hour
These metrics represent opportunity costs. Where elite-performing teams iterate rapidly and respond to market changes within hours, teams constrained by legacy systems operate at fundamentally different competitive speeds and cannot leverage the same opportunities.
Performance limitations also have organizational consequences that affect talent retention and operational stability. Talented engineers leave organizations where they spend more time fighting infrastructure than building products. Surveys show that inadequate tools and inefficient CI/CD processes rank among the top factors in turnover decisions for developers.
Additionally, pipeline fragility creates operational risk. Legacy systems often require manual intervention during critical deployments, which increases the likelihood of human error during critical releases. The resulting incidents consume engineering attention, erode customer trust, and require expensive postmortem processes.
Many organizations that recognize these problems make incremental improvements in an attempt to modernize their legacy CI/CD setup. They add new plugins to Jenkins, implement additional monitoring tools, or create wrapper scripts to reduce complexity.
However, incremental approaches fail to address the fundamental architectural limitations that hinder performance.
In fact, partial fixes usually create additional complexity rather than reducing it. New tools introduce additional integration points, require separate maintenance overhead, and create inconsistent developer experiences across different projects.
Heavily customized legacy systems often become even more difficult to operate than standard configurations.
The ROI of DevEx: How TeamCity delivers measurable returns
Modern, integrated CI/CD platforms like TeamCity enable elite performance through features specifically designed for developer productivity and operational reliability.
Elite teams using integrated platforms deploy 208 times more frequently than others, reduce lead times from months to days, and cut recovery times from weeks to just hours. These improvements result in reclaimed developer productivity, accelerated feature delivery, and reduced operational risk.
Let‚Äôs examine the specific capabilities that drive these returns:
Intuitive UI and build-chain visualization
TeamCity‚Äôs visual build-chain interface eliminates the cognitive overhead associated with complex YAML configurations and fragmented toolchains. Developers can understand pipeline dependencies, identify bottlenecks, and troubleshoot issues without specialized configuration knowledge.
Developer benefit: New team members become productive in hours rather than weeks. Experienced developers spend time building features instead of deciphering pipeline syntax. Surveys suggest that developers can reclaim up to a day per week when toolchain and process inefficiencies are reduced.
Business ROI: Higher engineer productivity translates to more features shipped per sprint and lower effective staffing costs per project. Let‚Äôs say you have a team of ten developers, each earning around $100K. Saving three hours per week could mean $75,000+ annually in reclaimed productivity.
Deep SCM and VCS integration
TeamCity provides easy integration with modern version control systems, automatically triggering builds based on commit patterns and providing contextual information about changes. This eliminates manual build triggers and reduces the errors associated with disconnected systems.
Developer benefit: Developers commit code and immediately receive build feedback without manual intervention. Contextual commit information enables faster debugging when issues occur. Teams eliminate the fifteen to thirty minutes typically required for manual build coordination, as well as the overhead of switching contexts.
Business ROI: Accelerated feedback cycles enable faster iteration and reduce the compound costs of late-discovered defects. Faster feedback loops, better automation, and more reliable pipelines substantially improve cycle time, which allows organizations to ship revenue-generating features faster, reduce time-to-market for new products, and increase the frequency of customer-facing improvements.
Advanced test intelligence
The developer experience of your CI platform directly determines how readily your team will adopt and maintain comprehensive test automation. TeamCity‚Äôs advanced testing capabilities ‚Äì like predictive test selection, flaky test detection, and historical test analytics ‚Äì remove friction from the testing workflow and make robust quality gates practical rather than aspirational.
Developer benefit: Fast, reliable test feedback enables developers to confidently execute code changes. Flaky tests no longer interrupt development flow or create false-positive alerts. Intelligent parallelization decreases test execution time by as much as 40‚Äì60 percent. And because the test parallelization is dynamic, the speed benefits can scale as new tests are added without drastically increasing run times.
Business ROI: Better automated quality control reduces defect escape costs and lowers incidents that impact customers.
Real-time monitoring and extensible plugins
TeamCity provides unified visibility across builds, tests, security scans, and infrastructure status through a single interface. The extensive plugin ecosystem enables teams to integrate with existing tools while maintaining consistent monitoring and alerting.
Developer benefit: Unified insight eliminates the context switching required to understand system state across multiple tools. Developers identify and resolve issues faster through consolidated monitoring. Custom plugins enable adaptation to evolve technology stacks without platform migration.
Business ROI: With fragmented toolchains, engineering teams spend substantial time configuring, maintaining, and monitoring disparate plugins and integrations, spending effort that delivers no direct customer value. TeamCity‚Äôs unified monitoring approach reduces this operational overhead so that engineers can focus on feature development rather than pipeline maintenance.
Scalable, performance-tuned architecture
TeamCity Cloud‚Äôs architecture scales efficiently as organizations grow, maintaining build performance even as project complexity increases. This eliminates the need for frequent replatforming and provides predictable operational costs. Because TeamCity Cloud‚Äôs infrastructure is managed for you, you also don‚Äôt need to worry about runners becoming outdated or aging out of usefulness as your application grows in complexity.
Developer benefit: Build times remain consistent as projects grow. Developers avoid the productivity hits associated with infrastructure capacity constraints. Teams can focus on feature development rather than infrastructure scaling decisions.
Business ROI: Deferred infrastructure spending and predictable operational expenses enable better budget planning. Organizations avoid the disruption and costs associated with emergency platform migrations when existing systems reach capacity limits.
In summary
Elite-performing teams operate at fundamentally different speeds than their competitors, enabling them to respond to market opportunities, recover from incidents, and iterate on customer feedback rapidly.
Upgrading to a developer-centric CI/CD platform like TeamCity is an investment with clear returns: reclaimed developer productivity, accelerated feature delivery, reduced operational risk, and improved customer satisfaction. Some organizations report payback in mere months when automation and tooling investments eliminate inefficiencies and reduce cycle times, though results depend on your organization‚Äôs scale and context.
The real risk lies in inaction.
While competitors migrate to modern platforms and achieve elite performance levels, organizations that maintain legacy systems fall further behind in capability and competitive position. The performance gap between elite and low-performing organizations continues to widen as modern platforms enable increasingly sophisticated development practices.
If your legacy tooling is holding your teams back and hampering performance, it might be time to make a change.

posts.creator: Anna Rovinskaia
posts.title: IntelliJ IDEA Conf 2026: Learn From the People Building the JVM Ecosystem
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
You‚Äôre invited to IntelliJ IDEA Conf 2026 ‚Äì a free online conference for developers working across the JVM ecosystem. Join us for two days of in-depth technical talks, practical insights, and conversations with experts who build and shape modern Java and Kotlin development.
The conference will take place online on March 26‚Äì27, 2026, with sessions livestreamed directly from the JetBrains studios.
What to expect
IntelliJ IDEA Conf 2026 will feature live sessions from engineers and developer advocates representing JetBrains, Oracle, AWS, Broadcom, Docker, Gradle, and other organizations shaping the JVM ecosystem.
Across two days, speakers will cover a broad range of topics relevant to modern Java and Kotlin development, including language evolution, enterprise Java, Spring-based applications, build tooling, containerized workflows, JVM performance, and data access technologies.
Several sessions will explore the growing role of AI in Java development ‚Äì from AI-assisted workflows and autonomous agents to practical use cases in everyday development. You‚Äôll also hear about GraalVM and polyglot development, accelerating builds with Maven and Gradle, working effectively with Docker, and troubleshooting complex applications with IntelliJ IDEA.
In addition to deep technical talks, the program includes discussions on the developer experience, open source, and community-driven tooling, offering perspectives from people who actively influence the technologies and tools used by millions of developers worldwide.
All sessions are grounded in real-world experience and focused on practical insights you can apply in professional JVM projects.
Stay tuned for the full schedule and complete list of speakers!
Why this online event is special
IntelliJ IDEA Conf 2026 is fully virtual and free to attend, making it easy to join from anywhere in the world. All sessions will be streamed live with high-quality production, so you can follow along in real time or catch up later.
Live chat and Q&A are a core part of the experience. You‚Äôll be able to ask questions during the sessions, engage directly with speakers, and connect with other developers attending the conference.
Every session will be recorded and published afterward, so even if you miss something live, you‚Äôll still have access to all the content.
How to join
Registration is free and open to everyone.
When you sign up, you can choose whether you want to attend all sessions or focus only on the ones most relevant to you. Closer to the event, we‚Äôll send you all the details you need to join the livestreams.
All sessions will be presented live, with time reserved for Q&A. We encourage you to participate, ask questions, and make the most of the opportunity to learn directly from the speakers.
After the conference, recordings will be available on the IntelliJ IDEA YouTube channel. Don‚Äôt forget to subscribe!
See you online!

posts.creator: Dmitrii Korovin
posts.title: TeamCity 2025.11.2 Is Now Available
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The second bug-fix update for TeamCity On-Premises 2025.11 is ready to be installed! In this update, we have addressed a number of issues, such as:
The ‚Äúbuildagent‚Äù user in TeamCity Linux agent images changed its UID from 1000 to 1001;
Dark theme inconsistencies in the Custom Run dialog;
Builds with artifact dependencies may get stuck in the ‚ÄúPreparing to start‚Äù phase;
The Agent Open Terminal button may disappear from the agent details page.
All TeamCity bug-fix updates include performance and security improvements, so we recommend that you never skip these minor updates. See TeamCity 2025.11.2 Release Notes for the complete list of resolved issues.
Why update?
Staying up to date with minor releases ensures your TeamCity instance benefits from the following:
Performance improvements.
Better compatibility with integrations.
Faster, more stable builds.
Enhanced security for your workflows.
Compatibility
TeamCity 2025.11.2 shares the same data format as all 2025.11.x releases. You can upgrade or downgrade within this series without the need for backup and restoration.
How to upgrade
Use the automatic update feature in your current TeamCity version.
Download the latest version directly from the JetBrains website.
Pull the updated TeamCity Docker image.
Need help?
Thank you for reporting issues and providing feedback! If you have questions or run into any problems, please let us know via the TeamCity Forum or Issue Tracker.
Happy building!

posts.creator: Maksim Zuev
posts.title: Platform Debugger Architecture Redesign for Remote Development in 2026.1
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The IntelliJ Platform provides a powerful debugger framework that plugins can extend to support various programming languages and runtime environments. To enable remote development scenarios ‚Äì where the IDE interface runs on your local machine while code executes on a remote server ‚Äì we‚Äôve redesigned the debugger architecture. This guide walks you through the changes and shows you how to migrate your plugin for 2026.1 and beyond.
Why split the debugger?
In the last several releases, we re‚Äëarchitected the IntelliJ Platform debugger to support Remote Development mode. The major change visible to users is that the Debugger tool window and breakpoints are now rendered on the frontend, while the backend hosts the active debugger session and communicates with the target process. As a result, the debugger experience in Remote Development mode is much more responsive and stable. However, these changes have modified the debugger implementation and might affect existing plugins.
To provide the same experience in both Remote Development and Local IDE modes, we use a single implementation for both. Therefore, the changes described in this guide can affect plugins in both modes.
Important: This guide focuses primarily on plugin support in Local mode. For migration steps for Remote Development mode, see the section below.
What‚Äôs changed?
To support Remote Development mode, we split the debugger into two parts: frontend and backend. The frontend is responsible for rendering the Debugger tool window (frames, variables‚Äô tree, inlays, etc.). The backend hosts the active debugger session started by a plugin and provides data to the frontend via RPC (Remote Procedure Call).
As a result of these changes, several debugger API contracts have changed.
The debugger UI is now created asynchronously, so older methods that access the debugger UI or the Debugger tab may cause race conditions.
The frontend implementation no longer works directly with entities provided by plugins via XDebugProcess and XSuspendContext. For example, XStackFrame, XValue, and other instances are no longer available on the frontend. Instead, we use FrontendXValue wrappers that cannot be cast to plugin‚Äëspecific XValue implementations.
Example: Suppose you have a plugin that implements a custom debugger. The plugin extends XDebugProcess as MyDebugProcess and provides custom implementations: MyStackFrame (which extends XStackFrame), MyValue (which extends XValue), and other entities. In addition to the backend implementation, the plugin provides an action that assumes the platform debugger UI operates on those entities directly (e.g. XValueNodeImpl contains MyValue).
Now that the debugger has been split, the platform debugger UI operates with FrontendXValue and other frontend wrappers instead (e.g. XValueNodeImpl now contains FrontendXValue). As a result, actions operating on the debugger UI may unexpectedly access frontend entities and fail to cast them to plugin entities (e.g. FrontendXValue is not an instance of MyValue). See the following sections for more details.
What should I do?
Test your plugin with the 2026.1 EAP. UI components and actions are the areas most likely to be affected.
Pay attention to error messages in the IDE log. Incorrect debugger API usage will be logged with the [Split debugger] message prefix and an explanation of the migration steps.
Two migration paths:
Depending on your plugin requirements, choose one of the following migration paths:
Local mode only ‚Äì Migrate from the affected APIs below to the recommended ones. Your plugin will work in Local IDE mode, but some functionality may work incorrectly in Remote Development.
Local + Remote Development modes ‚Äì Follow the Remote Development mode migration steps below to support both modes.
If you encounter unexpected API behavior, please report it in YouTrack.
Which APIs are affected in Local IDE mode?
The following APIs related to the debugger UI are deprecated and unsafe to use since 2026.1:
com.intellij.xdebugger.XDebugSession#getRunContentDescriptor ‚Äì deprecated and must not be used, as the frontend UI should not be accessed from the backend. See the Javadoc for more details.
com.intellij.xdebugger.XDebugSession#getUI ‚Äì deprecated and must not be used. Can lead to race conditions due to asynchronous creation of the frontend UI.
Workaround: Use com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.XDebugSessionImpl.runWhenUiReady.
com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.XDebugSessionImpl#getSessionTab (internal) ‚Äì deprecated and must not be used. Can also lead to race conditions.
Workaround: Use com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.XDebugSessionImpl.runWhenTabReady.
Which APIs are safe to use in Local IDE mode?
All APIs that provide data to the backend are valid and safe to use in Local mode, such as XDebugProcess, XSuspendContext, and the data they provide.
For creating debugger‚Äërelated actions, the following APIs are supported:
com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.actions.handlers.XDebuggerActionHandler
com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.ui.tree.actions.XDebuggerTreeActionBase
com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.ui.tree.actions.XFetchValueActionBase
These actions should not require changes in Local IDE mode. They have been adapted to use plugin‚Äëspecific entities instead of frontend wrappers to preserve compatibility with the older implementation.
Remote Development mode migration steps
The following APIs will NOT work in Remote Development mode:
UI and Debugger tab access:

com.intellij.xdebugger.XDebugSession#getUI
com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.XDebugSessionImpl#getSessionTab
com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.XDebugSessionImpl.runWhenTabReady
Base action classes that work with debugger nodes:

XDebuggerTreeActionBase
XFetchValueActionBase
Use these alternatives instead:
com.intellij.xdebugger.XDebugProcess.createTabLayouter ‚Äì use this to provide additional tabs in the Debugger tool window.
com.intellij.xdebugger.impl.XDebugSessionImpl.runWhenUiReady ‚Äì also works for adding tabs, but com.intellij.xdebugger.XDebugProcess.createTabLayouter is the recommended approach.
XDebuggerTreeBackendOnlyActionBase ‚Äì an alternative to XDebuggerTreeActionBase that works only with XValue instead of nodes.

SQLQueryFactoryÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ JDBC Î†àÎ≤®Ïùò Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Type-SafeÌïòÍ≤å ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎèÑÎ°ù ÎèÑÏôÄÏ§çÎãàÎã§.

@Service
class BatchInsertService(
    private val dataSource: DataSource
) {
    @Transactional
    fun executeBulkInsertWritersWithSql(writers: List<Writer>): Long {
        // 1. ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏î Î©îÌÉÄÎç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ Ï†ïÏùò
        val writerTable = RelationalPathBase(Writer::class.java, "writer", null, "writer")
        // 2. SQLQueryFactory ÏÉùÏÑ± (MySQL ÌÖúÌîåÎ¶ø ÏÇ¨Ïö©)
        val sqlQueryFactory = SQLQueryFactory(Configuration(MySQLTemplates()), dataSource)
        val insert = sqlQueryFactory.insert(writerTable)
        // 3. Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º BatchÏóê Ï∂îÍ∞Ä
        for (writer in writers) {
            insert.set(QWriter.writer.name, writer.name)
            insert.set(QWriter.writer.email, writer.email)
            insert.set(QWriter.writer.score, 1)
            insert.set(QWriter.writer.reputation, 1.toDouble())
            insert.set(QWriter.writer.active, true)
            insert.addBatch() // Î©îÎ™®Î¶¨Ïóê ÏøºÎ¶¨ Ï†ÅÏû¨
        }

        // 4. ÏùºÍ¥Ñ Ïã§Ìñâ
        return insert.execute()
    }
}

ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ïù¥ ÏòµÏÖòÏùÑ ÌôúÏÑ±ÌôîÌïòÎ©¥ ÎìúÎùºÏù¥Î≤Ñ Î†àÎ≤®ÏóêÏÑú Ïó¨Îü¨ Í∞úÏùò Insert Íµ¨Î¨∏ÏùÑ ÌïòÎÇòÏùò INSERT INTO ... VALUES (...), (...), (...) ÌòïÌÉúÏùò Multi-Value Insert Íµ¨Î¨∏ÏúºÎ°ú Ïû¨ÏûëÏÑ±(Rewrite)ÌïòÏó¨ Ï†ÑÏÜ°Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ ÎÑ§Ìä∏ÏõåÌÅ¨ Ìå®ÌÇ∑ ÏàòÎ•º ÌöçÍ∏∞Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ï§ÑÏù¥Í≥† Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î≤†Ïù¥Ïä§Ïùò ÌååÏã± ÎπÑÏö©ÏùÑ Ï†àÍ∞êÌïòÏó¨ ÏÑ±Îä•ÏùÑ Í∑πÎåÄÌôîÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

    @Test
fun `saveAll test`() {
    val rowsList = listOf(100, 200, 500, 1_000, 2_000, 5_000, 10_000)
    val iterations = 5

    rowsList.forEach { rows ->
        var totalTimeMillis = 0.0
        for (i in 1..iterations) {
            val uniqueWriters = (1..rows).map {
                Writer(name = "name-$i-$it", email = "email-$i-$it")
            }

            val stopWatch = StopWatch()
            stopWatch.start()
            writerRepository.saveAll(uniqueWriters)
            stopWatch.stop()

            if (i > 1) { // Ï≤´ ÌöåÏ∞® Ï†úÏô∏
                totalTimeMillis += stopWatch.totalTimeMillis
            }
        }
        val averageTimeMillis = totalTimeMillis / (iterations - 1)
        println("$rows Í±¥ saveAll ÌèâÍ∑† Ïã§Ìñâ ÏãúÍ∞Ñ: ${averageTimeMillis} ms")
    }
}

@Test
fun `executeBulkInsertWritersWithSql test`() {

    val iterations = 5

        var totalTimeMillis = 0.0

            stopWatch.stop()

posts.creator: Ïñ¥Îñ§Ïò§ÌõÑÏùò ÌîÑÎ¶¨Ïõ®Ïñ¥ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞
posts.title: AIÎäî Í±∞Ï∞ΩÌïú Í∏∞Ïà†Ïù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎã§? Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÎØ∏Ï≤ò Î™∞ÎûêÎçò ÏÉùÌôú ÏÜç Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•Ïùò ÏßÑÏßú ÏñºÍµ¥
posts.author: Ïñ¥Îñ§Ïò§ÌõÑÏùò ÌîÑÎ¶¨Ïõ®Ïñ¥ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞
posts.content:
Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Î™®Î•¥Îäî ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ïóê Ïö∞Î¶¨ ÏÇ∂ ÍπäÏàôÏù¥ ÌååÍ≥†Îì† Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•. Ï±óGPT Í∞ôÏùÄ Í±∞Ï∞ΩÌïú Í∏∞Ïà†Îßå AIÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÏÖ®ÎÇòÏöî? ÏÇ¨Ïã§ÏùÄ Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞, Ïä§Ìä∏Î¶¨Î∞ç ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§, Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ Ïö∞Î¶¨ Ïßë Í∞ÄÏ†ÑÏ†úÌíàÍπåÏßÄ, Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•ÏùÄ Îß§ÏùºÎß§Ïùº Ïö∞Î¶¨ Í≥ÅÏóêÏÑú ÏÇ∂ÏùÑ Îçî Ìé∏Î¶¨ÌïòÍ≥† Ïú§ÌÉùÌïòÍ≤å ÎßåÎì§Í≥† ÏûàÎãµÎãàÎã§. 2026ÎÖÑ, Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•Ïùò ÏßÑÏßú ÏñºÍµ¥ÏùÑ ÎßåÎÇòÎ≥ºÍπåÏöî?

ÏöîÏ¶ò Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•(AI)Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Îã®Ïñ¥Î•º ÎπºÎÜìÍ≥† Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÌïòÍ∏∞Îäî Ï†ïÎßê Ïñ¥Î†§Ïö¥ Í≤É Í∞ôÏïÑÏöî. Í±∞Î¶¨Î•º Í±∑Îã§ Î≥¥Î©¥ AI Í¥ÄÎ†® Í¥ëÍ≥†Í∞Ä ÎààÏóê ÎùÑÍ≥†, Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞ÏùÑ ÏºúÎ©¥ AI Í∏∞Î∞ò Ïï±Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÎìùÌïòÏ£†. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ AIÎ•º ÏïÑÏßÅÎèÑ ÏòÅÌôî ÏÜç Î°úÎ¥áÏù¥ÎÇò Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÎØ∏Îûò Í∏∞Ïà†Î°úÎßå ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÏãúÎäî Í≤ΩÌñ•Ïù¥ ÏûàÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÏïÑÏöî. ÏÜîÏßÅÌûà Ï†ÄÎèÑ Í∑∏Îû¨Í±∞Îì†Ïöî.

Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ ÎßêÏù¥Ï£†, Í≥∞Í≥∞Ïù¥ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥Î≥¥Î©¥ AIÎäî Ïù¥ÎØ∏ Ïö∞Î¶¨ ÏùºÏÉÅÏóê ÎÑàÎ¨¥ÎÇò ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å Ïä§Î©∞Îì§Ïñ¥ ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî ÏùòÏãùÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ïóê AIÏùò ÎèÑÏõÄÏùÑ Î∞õÏúºÎ©∞ ÏÇ¥ÏïÑÍ∞ÄÍ≥† ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî. ÎßàÏπò Í≥µÍ∏∞Ï≤òÎüº ÎßêÏù¥Ï£†. Ïò§ÎäòÏùÄ 2026ÎÖÑ ÌòÑÏû¨, Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÎØ∏Ï≤ò Î™∞ÎûêÎçò ÏÉùÌôú ÏÜç Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•Ïùò ÏßÑÏßú Î™®ÏäµÏùÑ ÌååÌó§Ï≥êÎ≥¥Í≥†, AIÍ∞Ä Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò ÏÇ∂ÏùÑ Îçî ÏâΩÍ≥† Ï¶êÍ≤ÅÍ≤å ÎßåÎìúÎäîÏßÄ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï¥Î≥¥Î†§ Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

Ïö∞Î¶¨ Í≥ÅÏóê ÎÑàÎ¨¥ÎÇò ÎãπÏó∞Ìïú Ï°¥Ïû¨, Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏ ÎπÑÏÑú

ÏïÑÏπ®Ïóê ÎààÏùÑ Îú®ÏûêÎßàÏûê ÎÇ†Ïî®Î•º Î¨ªÍ≥†, Ïª§Ìîº Î®∏Ïã†ÏùÑ ÏºúÎã¨ÎùºÍ≥† ÎßêÌïòÍ≥†, Ï¢ãÏïÑÌïòÎäî ÏùåÏïÖÏùÑ ÌãÄÏñ¥Îã¨ÎùºÍ≥† ÏöîÏ≤≠ÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÌóò, ÌòπÏãú ÏûàÏúºÏã†Í∞ÄÏöî? Î∞îÎ°ú Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏ Ïä§ÌîºÏª§ÎÇò Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìè∞Ïùò ÏùåÏÑ± ÎπÑÏÑúÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Ïù¥Î£®Ïñ¥ÏßÄÎäî ÏùºÏù¥Ï£†. Íµ¨Í∏Ä Ïñ¥ÏãúÏä§ÌÑ¥Ìä∏, Ïï†Ìîå ÏãúÎ¶¨, ÏÇºÏÑ± ÎπÖÏä§ÎπÑ, ÏïÑÎßàÏ°¥ ÏïåÎ†âÏÇ¨ Îì±ÏùÄ Ïù¥Ï†ú Ïö∞Î¶¨ÏóêÍ≤å ÎÑàÎ¨¥ÎÇò ÏùµÏàôÌïú Ïù¥Î¶ÑÏù¥ ÎêòÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏÇ¨Ïã§ Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ Î∞îÎ°ú Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä•Ïùò ÎåÄÌëúÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏòàÏãúÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÏïÑÏÖ®ÎÇòÏöî?

Ïù¥ Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏ ÎπÑÏÑúÎì§ÏùÄ Îã®ÏàúÌûà Î™ÖÎ†πÏùÑ ÏàòÌñâÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥, Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò ÏùåÏÑ±ÏùÑ Ïù∏ÏãùÌïòÍ≥†, ÏßàÎ¨∏Ïùò ÏùòÎèÑÎ•º ÌååÏïÖÌïòÎ©∞, Î∞©ÎåÄÌïú Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú Ï†ÅÏ†àÌïú ÎãµÎ≥ÄÏù¥ÎÇò ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Î•º Ï†úÍ≥µÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, “Ïò§Îäò Ï†ÄÎÖÅ Î©îÎâ¥ Ï∂îÏ≤úÌï¥ Ï§ò”ÎùºÍ≥† Î¨ºÏúºÎ©¥, Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Í≥ºÍ±∞ Í≤ÄÏÉâ Í∏∞Î°ùÏù¥ÎÇò Ï¶êÍ≤®Ï∞æÎäî Î†àÏãúÌîºÎ•º Î∂ÑÏÑùÌï¥ÏÑú Í∞úÏù∏ÌôîÎêú Ï∂îÏ≤úÏùÑ Ìï¥Ï£ºÎäî ÏãùÏù¥Ï£†. Ï†ÄÎäî ÏïÑÏπ®ÎßàÎã§ ÏïåÎ†âÏÇ¨ÏóêÍ≤å Ïò§ÎäòÏùò Îâ¥Ïä§Î•º ÏöîÏïΩÌï¥Îã¨ÎùºÍ≥† ÏöîÏ≤≠ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Ï∂úÍ∑º Ï§ÄÎπÑÎ•º ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏÑ∏ÏÉÅ ÏÜåÏãùÏùÑ Ìïú Î≤àÏóê Îì§ÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥ÏÑú Ï†ïÎßê Ìé∏Î¶¨Ìï¥Ïöî. Ïù¥Í±¥ Îã®ÏàúÌïú Í∏∞Ïà†Ïù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, Ï†ú Ìå®ÌÑ¥ÏùÑ ÌïôÏäµÌïòÍ≥† Ï†ÄÏóêÍ≤å ÎßûÏ∂∞Ï£ºÎäî AIÏùò Îä•Î†• ÎçïÎ∂ÑÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï©ÎãàÎã§.

2014ÎÖÑ ÏïÑÎßàÏ°¥ ÏóêÏΩî Ï∂úÏãú Ïù¥ÌõÑ, Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏ Ïä§ÌîºÏª§Îäî ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ ÏÜçÎèÑÎ°ú Ïö∞Î¶¨ ÏùºÏÉÅÏóê ÏûêÎ¶¨ Ïû°ÏïòÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî Í±∞Ïùò Î™®Îì† Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìôà Í∏∞Í∏∞ÏôÄ Ïó∞ÎèôÎêòÏñ¥ Ïßë ÏïàÏùò ÌóàÎ∏å Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ ÌÜ°ÌÜ°Ìûà ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏ£†.

‚úçÔ∏è Í∂ÅÍ∏àÏ¶ù Ìï¥Í≤∞ÏÇ¨Î∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï∞ΩÏûë ÎèÑÍµ¨ÍπåÏßÄ, LLMÏùò Î≥ÄÏã†

ÏµúÍ∑º Î™á ÎÖÑÍ∞Ñ Í∞ÄÏû• Îú®Í±∞Ïõ†Îçò AI Î∂ÑÏïºÎ•º ÍºΩÏúºÎùºÎ©¥ Îã®Ïó∞ ÎåÄÍ∑úÎ™® Ïñ∏Ïñ¥ Î™®Îç∏(LLM) Í∏∞Î∞òÏùò Ï±óÎ¥áÏùº Í±∞ÏòàÏöî. Ï±óGPT, Íµ¨Í∏Ä Ï†úÎØ∏Îãà, ÎßàÏù¥ÌÅ¨Î°úÏÜåÌîÑÌä∏ ÏΩîÌååÏùºÎüø Îì± Îã§ÏñëÌïú ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Îì§Ïù¥ ÏèüÏïÑÏ†∏ ÎÇòÏò§Î©¥ÏÑú Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÌÉêÏÉâ Î∞©Ïãù ÏûêÏ≤¥Î•º Î∞îÍøîÎ≤ÑÎ†∏Ï£†.

ÏòõÎÇ†ÏóêÎäî Ïñ¥Îñ§ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Í∞Ä Í∂ÅÍ∏àÌïòÎ©¥ Î∞±Í≥ºÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÏùÑ Îí§ÏßÄÍ±∞ÎÇò ÎèÑÏÑúÍ¥ÄÏóê Í∞ÄÏÑú Ï±ÖÏùÑ Ï∞æÏïÑÎ¥êÏïº ÌñàÏ£†. Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÎÑ∑ ÏãúÎåÄÍ∞Ä Ïó¥Î¶¨Î©¥ÏÑú Í≤ÄÏÉâ ÏóîÏßÑÏúºÎ°ú Îπ†Î•¥Í≤å Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Ï∞æÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÍ≤å ÎêòÏóàÏßÄÎßå, Ïó¨Ï†ÑÌûà ÏàòÎßéÏùÄ Í≤ÄÏÉâ Í≤∞Í≥º Ï§ëÏóêÏÑú ÌïÑÏöîÌïú Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏÑ†Î≥ÑÌïòÎäî Í±¥ Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Î™´Ïù¥ÏóàÏñ¥Ïöî. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÏßÄÍ∏àÏùÄ Ïñ¥Îñ§Í∞ÄÏöî? Ï±óÎ¥áÏóêÍ≤å ÏßàÎ¨∏ ÌïòÎÇòÎßå ÎçòÏßÄÎ©¥, Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÎÑ∑Ïùò Î∞©ÎåÄÌïú Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏàúÏãùÍ∞ÑÏóê ÏöîÏïΩÌïòÍ≥† Ï†ïÎ¶¨Ìï¥ÏÑú Ïö∞Î¶¨ÏóêÍ≤å ÌïÑÏöîÌïú ÎãµÏùÑ Îî±! Ï†úÏãúÌï¥Ï§çÎãàÎã§. Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÏßàÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú Ïó¨Îü¨ Í∞ÄÏßÄ Í¥ÄÏ†êÏù¥ÎÇò ÎåÄÏïàÍπåÏßÄÎèÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÎãà, Ï†ïÎßê ÎÜÄÎûçÏßÄ ÏïäÎÇòÏöî?

Ï†ÄÎäî ÏµúÍ∑ºÏóê Ïù∏ÌÖåÎ¶¨Ïñ¥Î•º Í≥†ÎØºÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ï±óÎ¥áÏùò ÎèÑÏõÄÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ Î∞õÏïòÏñ¥Ïöî. Í±∞Ïã§Ïóê Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÏÉâÍπîÏùò ÏÜåÌååÍ∞Ä Ïñ¥Ïö∏Î¶¥ÏßÄ, ÌòπÏùÄ ÌäπÏ†ï Í≥µÍ∞ÑÏóê Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÏãùÎ¨ºÏùÑ ÎÜìÏúºÎ©¥ Ï¢ãÏùÑÏßÄ ÎßâÏó∞ÌïòÍ≤å ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÎßå ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏóàÍ±∞Îì†Ïöî. Ï±óÎ¥áÏóêÍ≤å “Ïö∞Î¶¨ Ïßë Í±∞Ïã§ ÏÇ¨ÏßÑÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÎ©∞ Ïù¥ Í≥µÍ∞ÑÏóê Ïñ¥Ïö∏Î¶¨Îäî ÌòÑÎåÄÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏÜåÌåå ÎîîÏûêÏù∏ÏùÑ Ï∂îÏ≤úÌï¥Ï§ò”ÎùºÍ≥† ÏûÖÎ†•ÌñàÎçîÎãà, Î™á Ï¥à ÎßåÏóê Ïó¨Îü¨ Í∞ÄÏßÄ ÏãúÏïàÏùÑ Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÎ°ú ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìï¥Ï£ºÎçîÎùºÍ≥†Ïöî. Îòê, “Ïù¥Îü∞ Ïä§ÌÉÄÏùºÏùò ÏÜåÌååÎ•º ÌååÎäî ÎØøÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Íµ≠ÎÇ¥ Í∞ÄÍµ¨ ÏóÖÏ≤¥ 3Í≥≥ÏùÑ Ï∂îÏ≤úÌï¥Ï§ò”ÎùºÍ≥† ÏöîÏ≤≠ÌïòÎãà, Í¥ÄÎ†® Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏöîÏïΩÌï¥ÏÑú Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÎçïÎ∂ÑÏóê ÏãúÌñâÏ∞©Ïò§Î•º Ï§ÑÏù¥Í≥† ÏãúÍ∞ÑÍ≥º ÎπÑÏö©ÏùÑ Ï†àÏïΩÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÏ£†. Ïù¥Îü∞ Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ Ìï¥Î≥¥Î©¥ AIÍ∞Ä Îçî Ïù¥ÏÉÅ Í±∞Ï∞ΩÌïú Í∏∞Ïà†Ïù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, ÏÇ∂Ïùò ÏßàÏùÑ ÎÜíÏó¨Ï£ºÎäî ÎòëÎòëÌïú ÎπÑÏÑúÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Ï†àÍ∞êÌïòÍ≤å Îê©ÎãàÎã§.

‚ö†Ô∏è Ï±óÎ¥áÏùò ÎãµÎ≥ÄÏùÄ Ìï≠ÏÉÅ 100% Ï†ïÌôïÌïú Í≤ÉÏùÄ ÏïÑÎãê Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏñªÏùÑ ÎïåÎäî ÍµêÏ∞® Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÌïòÎäî ÏäµÍ¥ÄÏùÑ Îì§Ïù¥Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ï¢ãÏäµÎãàÎã§.

LLMÏù¥ Î∞îÍøîÎÜìÏùÄ Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÌÉêÏÉâÏùò Ìå®Îü¨Îã§ÏûÑ

Ìï≠Î™© Ï†ÑÌÜµÏ†Å Î∞©Ïãù (Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÎÑ∑ Ïù¥Ï†Ñ) Í≤ÄÏÉâ ÏóîÏßÑ (Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÎÑ∑ Ï¥àÍ∏∞) AI Ï±óÎ¥á (2026ÎÖÑ ÌòÑÏû¨)
Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÌöçÎìù Î∞©Ïãù Î∞±Í≥ºÏÇ¨Ï†Ñ, Ï±Ö, Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞Ä ÏßàÎ¨∏ ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìú Í≤ÄÏÉâ, ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏ Î∞©Î¨∏ ÏûêÏó∞Ïñ¥ ÏßàÎ¨∏, Ï¢ÖÌï© ÏöîÏïΩ Î∞è ÏÉùÏÑ±
Ï†ïÎ≥¥ ÏÑ†Î≥Ñ ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Ïò§Îûò Í±∏Î¶º (ÏàòÎèô ÏûëÏóÖ) ÎπÑÍµêÏ†Å Îπ†Î•¥ÎÇò ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê ÎÖ∏Î†• ÌïÑÏöî Îß§Ïö∞ Îπ†Î¶Ñ (AI ÏûêÎèô ÏÑ†Î≥Ñ)
Í∞úÏù∏Ìôî ÏàòÏ§Ä ÎÇÆÏùå Ï§ëÍ∞Ñ (Í≤ÄÏÉâ Í∏∞Î°ù Í∏∞Î∞ò) ÎÜíÏùå (ÎåÄÌôîÌòï ÎßûÏ∂§ Ï†ïÎ≥¥)

ÎÑ∑ÌîåÎ¶≠Ïä§Îßå Î¥êÎèÑ Ïïå Ïàò ÏûàÎäî AIÏùò ÏÑ¨ÏÑ∏Ìïú Ï∑®Ìñ• Ï†ÄÍ≤©

ÌïòÎ£®Î•º ÎßàÎ¨¥Î¶¨ÌïòÎ©∞ Ìé∏ÏïàÌïòÍ≤å ÏÜåÌååÏóê ÏïâÏïÑ ÎÑ∑ÌîåÎ¶≠Ïä§ÎÇò Ïú†ÌäúÎ∏åÎ•º ÏãúÏ≤≠ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎßåÌÅº ÌñâÎ≥µÌïú ÏàúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏûàÏùÑÍπåÏöî? posts.content:
ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏, ÏòÅÏÉÅ, Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÍπåÏßÄ Ï†ïÎ≥µÌñàÎã§Î©¥, Ïù¥Ï†ú 'Ïò§ÎîîÏò§' Ï∞®Î°ÄÏûÖÎãàÎã§! ÎπÑÏãº Ïú†Î£å ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Ïóê ÏßÄÏπòÏÖ®ÎÇòÏöî? 2026ÎÖÑ ÏµúÏã† AI Î¨¥Î£å Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÎèÑÍµ¨ 3Ï¢ÖÏúºÎ°ú ÌöåÏùòÎ°ù ÏûëÏÑ±, ÏùåÏïÖ ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅ, ÏùåÏÑ± Ìï©ÏÑ±ÏùÑ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò PCÏóêÏÑú ÎπÑÏö© Í±±Ï†ï ÏóÜÏù¥ Ìï¥Í≤∞ÌïòÏÑ∏Ïöî.

AI ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† Ï†ïÎ≥µ, Ïò§ÎîîÏò§Í∞Ä ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ ÌçºÏ¶ê!

Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂Ñ, 2026ÎÖÑ ÌòÑÏû¨ Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Ïù¥ÎØ∏ AIÎ°ú ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏, ÏòÅÏÉÅ, Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† ÏòÅÏó≠ÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïã§ÏÉÅ Ï†ïÎ≥µÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Ïú†ÎèÖ Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÏïûÏóêÏÑúÎßå ÎßâÎßâÌï®ÏùÑ ÎäêÍºàÎçò Î∂ÑÎì§ ÎßéÏúºÏãúÏ£†? ÎπÑÏãº TTS ÎπÑÏö©, Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅ, ÏàòÎèô ÌöåÏùòÎ°ù ÏûëÏÑ±Ïùò Î≤àÍ±∞Î°úÏõÄ… Ïù¥Ï†ú Í∑∏ Î™®Îì† Í±±Ï†ïÏùÑ ÎÇ¥Î†§ÎÜìÏúºÏÑ∏Ïöî! Ïò§ÎäòÏùÄ Îèà Ìïú Ìëº Îì§Ïù¥ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò PCÏóêÏÑú Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÏûëÏóÖÏùÑ Ìï¥Í≤∞Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ïú†Î£åÍ∏â AI Î¨¥Î£å ÎèÑÍµ¨ 3Í∞ÄÏßÄÎ•º ÏÜåÍ∞úÌï¥ ÎìúÎ¶¥ Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§. Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏßÅÏ†ë Ïç®Î≥¥Îãà, Ï†ïÎßê ÎÜÄÎùºÏõÄÏùò Ïó∞ÏÜçÏù¥ÏóàÏñ¥Ïöî. ÏùåÏÑ± Î∂ÑÏÑùÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏùåÏïÖ ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅ, Í≥†ÌíàÏßà ÏùåÏÑ± Ìï©ÏÑ±ÍπåÏßÄ, Ïù¥ Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú ÎèÑÍµ¨Îì§Í≥º Ìï®Íªò Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† Ï†úÏûëÏùò Ïã†ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ•º Í≤ΩÌóòÌï¥ Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî!

AI Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ Îû©: ÏùåÏÑ±&ÏùåÏïÖ, Ïã¨Ï∏µ Î∂ÑÏÑù Ïõπ Ïï±

Ï≤´ Î≤àÏß∏ ÎèÑÍµ¨Îäî AI Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ Îû©ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÌöåÏùò ÎÖπÏùåÏù¥ÎÇò ÏùåÏïÖ ÌååÏùºÏùÑ Î∂ÑÏÑùÌï¥Ïïº Ìï† Îïå, ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò Íµ¨Ï°∞Î•º ÌååÏïÖÌïòÎäî ÏùºÏù¥ Ï†ïÎßê Í≥†Ïó≠Ïù¥Ï£†? AI Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ Îû©ÏùÄ Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏûëÏóÖÏùÑ ÏûêÎèôÏúºÎ°ú Ï≤òÎ¶¨Ìï¥Ï£ºÎäî Ïõπ Í∏∞Î∞ò ÎèÑÍµ¨ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò Ï†úÎØ∏ÎÇòÏù¥ AIÏôÄ Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÏùò Ïõπ Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ APIÎ•º Í≤∞Ìï©Ìï¥, Ïò§ÎîîÏò§Ïùò ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÎÇ¥Ïö©Í≥º Í∏∞Ïà†Ï†ÅÏù∏ Ïã†Ìò∏ Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º ÎèôÏãúÏóê Î∂ÑÏÑùÌï¥Ï§çÎãàÎã§. Î≥ÑÎèÑ ÏÑ§Ïπò ÏóÜÏù¥ Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÏóêÏÑú Î∞îÎ°ú ÏÇ¨Ïö© Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï¥ÏÑú Ï†ïÎßê Ìé∏Î¶¨Ìï¥Ïöî.

ÌöåÏùòÎ°ù ÏûêÎèô ÏûëÏÑ±! ÏùåÏÑ± Ïù∏ÌÖîÎ¶¨Ï†ÑÏä§ Í∏∞Îä•

ÏùåÏÑ± ÌååÏùºÏùÑ ÏóÖÎ°úÎìúÌïòÍ≥† 'Î∂ÑÏÑù ÏãúÏûë' Î≤ÑÌäºÏùÑ ÎàÑÎ•¥Î©¥, ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ ÏùåÏÑ± Ïù∏ÌÖîÎ¶¨Ï†ÑÏä§ Î¶¨Ìè¨Ìä∏Í∞Ä ÏÉùÏÑ±Îê©ÎãàÎã§. ÌôîÏûê Ïàò, Ïñ∏Ïñ¥, Ïû¨ÏÉù ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÄ Í∏∞Î≥∏Ïù¥Í≥†, Ï†ÑÏ≤¥ ÎåÄÌôîÏùò ÌïµÏã¨ ÏöîÏïΩ, ÌôîÏûêÎ≥Ñ Î∞úÏñ∏ Î∂ÑÏÑù, Ï∞∏Ïó¨Ïú® Ï∞®Ìä∏ÍπåÏßÄ Ï†úÍ≥µÎê©ÎãàÎã§. ÌäπÌûà ÌôîÏûêÎ≥ÑÎ°ú Ï†ïÎ¶¨Îêú ÎåÄÌôî Í∏∞Î°ùÏùÄ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÍπåÏßÄ ÌëúÏãúÎêòÏñ¥ ÌïÑÏöîÌïú Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ Ï∞æÍ∏∞ Ïö©Ïù¥Ìï¥Ïöî. Ïù¥Ï†ú ÌÅ¥Î¶≠ Ìïú Î≤àÏúºÎ°ú ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïú ÎπÑÏ¶àÎãàÏä§ Î¨∏ÏÑúÎ•º ÎßàÌÅ¨Îã§Ïö¥Ïù¥ÎÇò PDFÎ°ú Îã§Ïö¥Î°úÎìúÌï¥ Í≥µÏú†Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏúºÎãà, ÌöåÏùòÎ°ù ÏûëÏÑ± ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÄ Ìôï Ï§ÑÏñ¥Îì§ Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§.

ÏùåÏïÖÏùò Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÌååÌó§ÏπòÎã§! ÎÆ§ÏßÅ Îî• Îã§Ïù¥Î∏å Í∏∞Îä•

ÏùåÏïÖ Î∂ÑÏÑù Í∏∞Îä•ÎèÑ Í∞ïÎ†•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. ÏùåÏïÖ ÌååÏùºÏùÑ ÏóÖÎ°úÎìúÌïòÎ©¥ Ïû•Î•¥, ÌÇ§(Key), BPMÏùÄ Î¨ºÎ°† Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÌíàÏßà Î∂ÑÏÑù, Ïä§ÌÖú Î∂ÑÏÑù(Î≥¥Ïª¨, Î≤†Ïù¥Ïä§, ÎìúÎüº Îì± ÌååÌä∏Î≥Ñ ÌäπÏßï) Í≤∞Í≥ºÍπåÏßÄ ÏÉÅÏÑ∏Ìûà Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï§çÎãàÎã§. Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ Suno AI ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏Í∞Ä ÏûêÎèô ÏÉùÏÑ±ÎêòÏñ¥ ÎπÑÏä∑Ìïú ÏùåÏïÖÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§ ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî. 'Ïã†Ìò∏Ï≤òÎ¶¨' ÌÉ≠ÏóêÏÑúÎäî Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÌååÌòïÏùò ÏãúÍ∞Ñ ÏãúÎ¶¨Ï¶à, MFCC, ÌÅ¨Î°úÎßà Ï∞®Ìä∏ Îì±ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ ÏÜåÎ¶¨Ïùò Î¨ºÎ¶¨Ï†Å Ïã§Ï≤¥Î•º Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î°ú ÌôïÏù∏Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

 

 

 

Ô∏è Mastering Studio: ÎÇ¥ PCÏóêÏÑú Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÍ∏â ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅ

Îëê Î≤àÏß∏ ÎèÑÍµ¨Îäî Mastering StudioÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÏùåÏïÖ ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅ, ÎπÑÏãº ÎπÑÏö©Í≥º Î≥µÏû°Ìï® ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎßùÏÑ§Ïù¥ÏÖ®Ï£†? Ïù¥ Ïï±ÏùÄ Íµ¨Í∏Ä Gemini AIÏôÄ Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†Ä Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ Ï≤òÎ¶¨ Í∏∞Ïà†Î°ú Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò Ïª¥Ìì®ÌÑ∞ÏóêÏÑú ÏßÅÏ†ë ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅÏùÑ Ìï¥Ï§çÎãàÎã§. ÌååÏùºÏùÑ ÏÑúÎ≤ÑÎ°ú Ï†ÑÏÜ°Ìï† ÌïÑÏöî ÏóÜÏñ¥ Î≥¥Ïïà Í±±Ï†ïÎèÑ ÏóÜÍ≥†Ïöî. Ïó≠Ïãú ÏÑ§ÏπòÍ∞Ä ÌïÑÏöî ÏóÜÎäî Ïõπ Ïï±Ïù¥Îùº ÏïÑÏ£º Ìé∏Î¶¨Ìï¥Ïöî.

AIÍ∞Ä ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Ï£ºÎäî ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅ

Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÌååÏùºÏùÑ ÏóÖÎ°úÎìúÌïòÎ©¥ ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞ÎßÅÏùÑ ÏãúÏûëÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. 12Í∞ÄÏßÄ ÏÇ¨Ïö¥Îìú ÌîÑÎ°úÌïÑ ÌîÑÎ¶¨ÏÖã Ï§ëÏóêÏÑú ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò, AI Î°úÏßÅ ÏÉùÏÑ±Í∏∞Î•º ÌôúÏö©Ìï¥ Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî. posts.content:
ÏµúÍ∑º Í∏∞ÌöåÍ∞Ä ÎêòÏñ¥ÏÑú Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÏùò Ïª§Î¶¨Ïñ¥Ïóê Í¥ÄÌïú Î∞úÌëúÎ•º ÌñàÎã§.
Î∞úÌëú Ï£ºÏ†úÎäî "ÌÉêÏöï ÏïåÍ≥†Î¶¨Ï¶òÏ≤òÎüº ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Í∞Å Îã®Í≥ÑÎ≥ÑÎ°ú ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôîÎêú ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏùÑ ÌïòÎäêÎùº Ï†ÑÏ≤¥ ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôîÎ•º ÎÜìÏπòÎäî Ïö∞Î•º Î≤îÌïòÏßÄ ÎßêÎùº" ÏòÄÎã§.
(Ïù¥Ïóê Í¥ÄÌï¥ÏÑúÎèÑ Îî∞Î°ú Í∏ÄÎ°ú Ïì∏ ÏòàÏ†ïÏù¥Îã§.)

Í∑∏ Î∞úÌëúÏóêÏÑú "Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í≤ΩÌóòÍ≥º ÎÇòÏÅú Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÄ ÏóÜÏúºÎ©∞, Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌÉúÎèÑÏôÄ ÎÇòÏÅú ÌÉúÎèÑÎßå ÏûàÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§" ÎùºÎäî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º ÎìúÎ†∏Îã§.

Î∞úÌëúÍ∞Ä ÎÅùÎÇòÍ≥† QnA Îïå "Í∑∏Îüº Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌÉúÎèÑÏôÄ ÎÇòÏÅú ÌÉúÎèÑÎ•º Í∞ÄÎ•¥Îäî Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏù¥ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÎêòÎÇòÏöî?" ÎùºÎäî ÏßàÎ¨∏ÏùÑ Î∞õÏïòÎã§.

ÎØ∏Î¶¨ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥Îëî ÏßàÎ¨∏ÏùÄ ÏïÑÎãàÏòÄÏñ¥ÏÑú Í≥∞Í≥∞Ìûà ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥Î≥¥Í≥† ÎÇòÏÑú Îã§ÏùåÍ≥º Í∞ôÏù¥ ÎãµÎ≥Ä ÎìúÎ†∏Îã§.

"ÏßÄÍ∏à Ï£ºÏñ¥ÏßÑ Ïù¥ ÏùºÏù¥ Ïª§Î¶¨Ïñ¥Ïóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÎÉê/ÏïàÎêòÎÉêÎ•º ÎÅäÏûÑÏóÜÏù¥ ÌåêÎã®ÌïòÎäî Í±¥ Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌÉúÎèÑÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎãå Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§.
Ïª§Î¶¨Ïñ¥Ïóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÏïàÎêòÎäî ÏùºÏù¥Î©¥ ÏûòÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≤å ÎêúÎã§.
Í∑∏Îü¨Î©¥ Í≤∞Íµ≠ Í∑∏ ÏùºÏùÄ ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÏïàÎêòÎäî Í≤ΩÌóòÏúºÎ°ú ÎßàÎ¨¥Î¶¨ ÎêúÎã§.

Î∞òÎ©¥, Í∑∏ ÏùºÏù¥ Ïª§Î¶¨Ïñ¥Ïóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ Îê†ÏßÄ ÏïàÎê†ÏßÄ ÏÉÅÍ¥ÄÏóÜÏù¥ Ïù¥ ÏùºÏùÑ ÏûòÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎßå ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§Î©¥ Í∑∏Í≤å Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥Îì† Ïù¥ÌõÑÏóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Í∞Ä ÎßéÎã§.

Ï¢ãÏïÑÌïòÎäî ÏùºÏùÑ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌï† Ïàò ÏóÜÎäî ÏÉÅÌô©Ïù¥ÎùºÎ©¥ Ï£ºÏñ¥ÏßÑ Ïùº Í∑∏ ÏûêÏ≤¥Î•º Ï¢ãÏïÑÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌÉúÎèÑÏù∏ Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§.
Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Í∑∏ ÏùºÏùÑ Ï¢ãÏïÑÌïòÎ†§Î©¥, Í∑∏ ÏùºÏùÑ ÏûòÌï¥ÏïºÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ÏûòÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú ÎÖ∏Î†• Í≥ºÏ†ïÎì§Ïù¥ Í≤∞Íµ≠ÏùÄ Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í≤ΩÌóòÏúºÎ°ú Í∞àÎ¨¥Î¶¨ ÎêòÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§."

Ïó¨Îü¨ Ï±ÑÎÑêÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎ∂ÑÎì§Ïùò Í≥†ÎØºÏùÑ Îì£Îã§Î≥¥Î©¥ "ÎØ∏ÎûòÏóê ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Í∞ÄÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ ÌöåÏÇ¨, ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ ÏßÅÎ¨¥Î•º Ï†ïÌï¥ÎëêÍ≥†" ÌòÑÏû¨Ïùò Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ ÏÑ§Í≥ÑÌïòÎäîÎç∞ Í±∞Í∏∞ÏÑú Î∂àÏùºÏπòÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Í∞Ä ÏÉùÍ∏∞Î©¥ Î∂àÌñâÌïòÎã§Í≥† ÎäêÎÅºÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Î•º ÎßéÏù¥ Î¥§Îã§.

  • Ìï©Í≤©Ìïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÌíÄÏä§ÌÉùÏùÑ ÏõêÌïòÎäîÎç∞ Ï†ÄÎäî Î∞±ÏóîÎìú Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÍ∞Ä ÎêòÍ≥† Ïã∂Ïñ¥ÏÑú Î∞±ÏóîÎìúÎßå Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê Í≥ÑÏÜç ÏßÄÏõêÌï¥Î≥¥Î†§Í≥†Ïöî.
  • ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤Ñ Î∞±ÏóîÎìú Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎ°ú Ï∑®ÏóÖÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄÎç∞ ÌòÑÏû¨Îäî SI ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïó¨ÏÑú ÌîÑÎ°†Ìä∏ÏóîÎìú, Ïù∏ÌîÑÎùº Îì± Ïó¨Îü¨Í∞ÄÏßÄÎ•º Îã§ ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏñ¥ÏÑú Í≥†ÎØºÏù¥Îã§.
  • ÎπÖÌÖåÌÅ¨ Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎ°ú Ïù¥ÏßÅÌï† Í≥ÑÌöçÏù∏Îç∞, ÌòÑÏû¨Îäî Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖÏù¥Îùº MSA, k8s Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ Î™ªÌï¥Î≥¥Í≥† ÏûàÎã§. ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏóêÏÑ† Ï†ÄÎü∞ ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏúºÎ°úÏùò Í∞úÏÑ† ÏùºÏ†ïÏùÑ Ï†ÑÌòÄ Ï£ºÏßÄ ÏïäÏïÑÏÑú Í≥†ÎØºÏù¥Îã§.
  • Ïã§ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Ïú†Ï†Ä Ìä∏ÎûòÌîΩÏùÑ Î∞õÏïÑÎ≥¥Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄÎç∞, ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏóêÏÑ† Í≥ÑÏÜç ÎÇ¥Î∂Ä Ïñ¥ÎìúÎØº Í∞úÏÑ† ÏùºÍ∞êÎßå Ï£ºÏñ¥ÏÑú Í≥†ÎØºÏù¥Îã§.

ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎåÄÎ°ú ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôîÎêú ÏÑ†ÌÉùÎßå Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏùÄ Ïûò ÏóÜÎã§.

Ï£ºÎ≥ÄÏùò Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏãúÎãàÏñ¥ Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎ∂ÑÎì§ÏùÑ Î≥¥Î©¥ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÎ≥¥Îã§ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎåÄÎ°úÏùò Ïª§Î¶¨Ïñ¥ Ìå®Ïä§Î•º ÏàúÏ∞®Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î∞üÏïÑÏò§Ïã† Î∂ÑÎì§ÏùÄ ÎßéÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§.

Í∑∏Î†áÏßÄÎßå Ïñ¥Îäê ÏùºÏ†ï Í∂§ÎèÑÏóê Ïò§Î•¥Ïã† ÏÑ†Î∞∞Îì§ÏùÑ Î≥¥Î©¥ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ "Î≥∏Ïù∏ÏùÄ Ïö¥Ïù¥ Ï¢ãÏïÑÏÑú Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í≤ΩÌóòÎì§ÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ ÌñàÍ≥†, ÎçïÎ∂ÑÏóê Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í∏∞ÌöåÎ•º ÏñªÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÎã§" ÎùºÍ≥† Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ ÌïòÏã†Îã§.

ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÄ Ïö∞Ïó∞Ìïú Í∏∞ÌöåÎ°ú ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÏùºÏùÑ Îß°Í≤å ÎêòÍ≥† , Í∑∏ Ïùº ÏûêÏ≤¥Î•º ÏûòÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÎçò Í≥ºÏ†ïÏóêÏÑú ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ ÏñªÍ≤å ÎêòÍ≥†, Í∑∏ ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í≤ΩÌóòÏúºÎ°ú ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í∏∞ÌöåÎ•º ÏñªÍ≤åÎêòÎäî Í∑∏Îü∞ Í≥ºÏ†ïÎì§ÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥Îì§ Í≤™ÏúºÏÖ®Îã§.

ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏßÄÎÇòÍ≥†Î≥¥Îãà Í∑∏Í≤å Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í≤ΩÌóòÏù∏ Í≤ÉÏùÑ Ïïå Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ÏßÄ, ÏãúÏûëÌïòÎäî Îã®Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑú ÌåêÎã®Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎã§.

Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÍ∏∞ Ï†ÑÏóê Ïù¥Í≤å ÎÇòÌïúÌÖå Ï¢ãÏùÄÏßÄ ÏïÑÎãåÏßÄÎ•º ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Í∏∏Í≤å ÌåêÎã®Ìï† ÌïÑÏöîÎäî ÏóÜÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§.

Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥Îì† Í∑∏Í±∏ Ïûò ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÎßå Î∞îÍæ∏Ïñ¥ÎèÑ Í∑∏Í±¥ Ï†ÑÎ∂Ä Îã§ ÎÇòÏóêÍ≤å ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÎäî Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥ ÎêòÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§.

Í∑∏Îü∞ Î©¥ÏóêÏÑú Îä¶ÍπéÏù¥ Ï≤úÏû¨Îì§Ïùò ÎπÑÎ∞Ä ÎèÑ Ï∂îÏ≤úÌïúÎã§.

Ìï©Í≤©Ìïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÌíÄÏä§ÌÉùÏùÑ ÏõêÌïòÎäîÎç∞ Ï†ÄÎäî Î∞±ÏóîÎìú Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÍ∞Ä ÎêòÍ≥† Ïã∂Ïñ¥ÏÑú Î∞±ÏóîÎìúÎßå Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê Í≥ÑÏÜç ÏßÄÏõêÌï¥Î≥¥Î†§Í≥†Ïöî.

Î≥∏Ïù∏Ïù¥ ÏñºÍµ¥Ïù¥ ÎëêÍ∫ºÏö¥ Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÏù¥Í±∞ÎÇò, ÎòêÎäî Ï£ºÎ≥ÄÏóê Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÏñºÍµ¥Ïù¥ ÎëêÍ∫ºÏö¥ Ï≤†Î©¥Ìîº ÏπúÍµ¨ÏôÄ ÏßÄÏù∏Ïù¥ Ìï≠ÏÉÅ Î™á Î™ÖÏî© ÎàÑÍµ¨ÎÇò ÏûàÏùÑ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÎäî Îßê Í∑∏ÎåÄÎ°ú ÏñºÍµ¥Ïù¥ ÎëêÍ∫ºÏõåÏÑú ÎÇ®Ïùò ÎπÑÌåêÏùÑ Ïã†Í≤Ω Ïì∞ÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî ÎªîÎªîÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏùÑ ÎúªÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ‚ÄòÏñºÍµ¥Ïóê Ï≤†ÌåêÏùÑ ÍπîÏïòÎã§‚ÄôÎùºÎäî ÎßêÎèÑ Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî ÏûêÏ£º ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïúÎã§. Ïù¥ ÎßêÏùÄ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å, Ïñ∏Ï†ú Ïì∞Ïù¥ÎÉêÏóê Îî∞Îùº Í∏çÏ†ïÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏùòÎØ∏Î•º Í∞ÄÏßà ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÍ≥†, Î∂ÄÏ†ïÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏùòÎØ∏Î•º Í∞ÄÏßà ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïò§ÎäòÏùÄ ÏïÑÏ£º Í∏çÏ†ïÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏùòÎØ∏ÏóêÏÑúÏùò Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï¥ Î≥¥Î†§Í≥† ÌïúÎã§.
ÏñºÎßà Ï†ÑÏóê ÎØ∏Íµ≠Ïùò ÏäàÌçº Ïñ¥ÎîîÏóêÏÑúÎÇò Î≥º Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ï†ÄÎãπ Í∞ÑÏãù Ïä§ÌÇ§ÎãàÎî•Îìú(SkinnyDipped)Ïùò Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º ÌåüÏ∫êÏä§Ìä∏Î°ú Îì§ÏóàÎã§. Ï¥àÏΩî ÏΩîÌåÖ ÏïÑÎ™¨ÎìúÏù∏Îç∞, Ï£ºÎ°ú Îã§ÌÅ¨Ï¥àÏΩúÎ¶øÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÍ≥† ÏΩîÌåÖÏùÑ ÏïÑÏ£º ÏñáÍ≤å Ìï¥ÏÑú Îã§Î•∏ Í∞ÑÏãùÎ≥¥Îã§ ÎãπÍ≥º Ïó¥ÎüâÏù¥ ÎÇÆÏùÄ Ï†úÌíàÏù∏Îç∞, Î™®Îì† Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Ïõ¨ÎßåÌïú TV ÎìúÎùºÎßàÎ≥¥Îã§ ÎìúÎùºÎßàÌã±ÌïòÎìØÏù¥, Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Ïû¨ÎØ∏ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Ï¥àÍ∏∞ÏóêÎäî ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Îã§Î•∏ Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖÏùò Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Ï¥àÍ∏∞ÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ Ìï≠ÏÉÅ Î∞úÍ≤¨ÌïòÎäî Í≥µÌÜµÏ†êÏù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎäîÎç∞, Î∞îÎ°ú Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïùò Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÏôÄ ÎªîÎªîÏä§Îü¨ÏõÄÏù¥Îã§. ÏóÑÎßàÏôÄ Îî∏Ïù¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïù∏Îç∞ Ï†úÌíàÏùÑ Ïò§ÌîÑÎùºÏù∏ Ïú†ÌÜµÏóÖÏ≤¥Ïóê ÏûÖÏ†êÏãúÌÇ§Í∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑú Ï¥àÎ∞òÏóêÎäî Îëê Î∂ÑÏù¥ Î≥ÑÏùòÎ≥Ñ ÏßìÏùÑ Îã§ ÌñàÎã§. ÏùºÎã® Whole Foods ÏûÖÏ†êÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥ Í∞ÑÏãù Îã¥ÎãπÏûêÎ•º ÎßåÎÇòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑú Îß§Ïùº Îß§Ïû•ÏóêÏÑú ÌïòÏóºÏóÜÏù¥ Í∏∞Îã§Î¶∞ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÏûàÍ≥†(Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Ìà¨ÏûêÌïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò ÎåÄÌëúÎèÑ Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ìïú Ï†ÅÏù¥ ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥Í±¥ ÏöîÏÉàÎèÑ Ïûò Î®πÌûàÎäî Î∞©Î≤ïÏù¥Îã§.), Îçî Ïû¨ÎØ∏ÏûàÏóàÎçò ÏóêÌîºÏÜåÎìúÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Î≥∏ÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÏûàÎçò ÏãúÏï†ÌãÄÏùò Íµ¨Í∏Ä Í±¥Î¨ºÏóê Î™∞Îûò Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÏÑú, Íµ¨ÎÇ¥ÏãùÎãπÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥Ïä¨Î†ÅÍ±∞Î¶¨Î©¥ÏÑú ÏâêÌîÑÎ•º Ï∞æÏïòÍ≥†, Ïä§ÌÇ§ÎãàÎî•Îìú Ï†úÌíàÏùÑ Íµ¨Í∏Ä ÏßÅÏõêÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å Í∞ÑÏãùÏúºÎ°ú Ï†úÍ≥µÌï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§Í≥† ÏÑ§ÎìùÌïú Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Îã§.
Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎëêÍ∫ºÏö¥ ÎÇØÏßùÏúºÎ°ú Í≥†Í∞ùÏÇ¨, Ìà¨ÏûêÏÇ¨, ÌòëÎ†•ÏÇ¨Ïóê Ï≥êÎì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÎäî Í±¥ ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎäî Îß§Ïö∞ ÎßéÏùÄ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÍ∞Ä Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Ï¥àÍ∏∞Ïóê ÌñàÎçòÌï† ÏàòÎ∞ñÏóê ÏóÜÏóàÎçò Í≥µÌÜµÎêú ÌïÑÏàò ÏΩîÏä§Ïù∏Îç∞, Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎã§ Î≥¥Î©¥ ÎàÑÍµ¨ÎÇò Îã§ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî ÏãúÏ†êÏù¥ ÏûàÎã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ï†ïÎßê ÏÑ±Í≥µÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂Îã§Î©¥ Î™®Îì† Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÎ•º ÍπîÍ≥†, ÏùºÎ∞òÏù∏Îì§ÏùÄ Ï™ΩÌåîÎ†§ÏÑú Ï†àÎåÄÎ°ú ÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÎäî, Í∑∏Îü∞ ÏùºÎì§ÏùÑ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§.
ÎÇòÎèÑ Ïò§ÎûòÏ†ÑÏóê ÏòÅÏóÖÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ï≤†Î©¥Ìîº ÏòÅÏóÖÏùÑ ÌñàÏóàÍ≥†, ÎÆ§ÏßÅÏâêÏù¥ÌÅ¨Î•º ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑúÎèÑ Ïó¨Îü¨ Î≤à Ïù¥Îü∞ Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥ ÏûàÍ≥†, Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±ÏùÑ Ï≤òÏùå ÏãúÏûëÌï† ÎïåÎèÑ Í∑∏ÎÉ• Ïó¨Í∏∞Ï†ÄÍ∏∞ Ï≥êÎì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÏÑú Îã¨ÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≥†Ïûê ÌïòÎäî ÏùºÏùÑ ÏãúÎèÑÌï¥ Î≥∏ Ï†ÅÏù¥ ÏûàÎã§. Î™®Îì† Ï≥êÎì§Ïñ¥Í∞êÏù¥ ÏÑ±Í≥µÌïòÏßÑ Î™ªÌñàÍ≥†, Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≤ΩÏö∞ÏóêÎäî Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÍ∞Ä Ï∞¢Ïñ¥ÏßÄÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÌñàÏßÄÎßå, Ïñ¥Ï®åÎì† ÎÇòÎäî Ï†ïÎßê Í∞ÑÏ†àÌñàÍ≥†, Í∑∏ Í∞ÑÏ†àÌï®Ïù¥ ÎãπÏãúÏóê Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎëêÍ∫ºÏö¥ ÎÇØÏßùÏùÑ ÌòïÏÑ±Ìï¥ Ï§Ä Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§.
ÎÇòÎèÑ Ïù¥Îü∞ Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ ÏßÅÏ†ë Ìï¥Î¥§Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Ïö∞Î¶¨ Ìà¨ÏûêÏÇ¨ ÎåÄÌëúÎãòÎì§ÏóêÍ≤åÎèÑ Í∞ÄÎÅî Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§Í≥† ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ ‚ÄúÏ†ÄÎäî Í∑∏Îü∞ Í±∞ ÏõêÎûò Î™ªÌï¥Ïöî‚Äù , ‚ÄúÎ≠ê, Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤åÍπåÏßÄ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎÇòÏöî?‚ÄùÎùºÎäî ÎßêÏùÑ ÌïúÎã§. ÎÇòÎäî ‚ÄúÎÑ§, Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤åÍπåÏßÄ Ìï¥Ïïº Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.‚ÄùÎùºÍ≥† ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÎ•º ÍπîÍ≥† ÌñâÎèôÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§ÏùÄ Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å ÎßéÏßÄ ÏïäÎã§.
Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Ïù¥Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Ïûò Î™®Î•¥Îäî ÏÇ¨Ïã§Ïù¥ ÌïòÎÇò ÏûàÎã§. ÏúÑÏóêÏÑú ÎßêÌïú Ïä§ÌÇ§ÎãàÎî•Îìú Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎÇò Í≥ºÍ±∞Ïùò ÎÇò Í∞ôÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎèÑ ÌÉúÏñ¥ÎÇ† ÎïåÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï™ΩÌåîÎ¶ºÏùÑ Î™®Î•¥Í≥†, ÎÇ®Ïùò ÏãúÏÑ†ÏùÑ Ïã†Í≤Ω Ïì∞ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥†, Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÏòÄÎçò Í±¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îì§ÎèÑ ÎãπÏó∞Ìûà Ïïà ÎßåÎÇòÏ£ºÎ†§Í≥† ÌïòÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïùò ÏÇ¨Î¨¥Ïã§Ïóê Î∂àÏë• Ï≥êÎì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÍ±∞ÎÇò, ÎàÑÍ∞Ä Í±¥Î¨ºÏùò Ï∂úÏûÖÍµ¨Î•º Ïó¥Ïñ¥Ï£ºÍ∏∞Î•º ÌïòÏóºÏóÜÏù¥ Ï∂îÏúÑÏóêÏÑú Í∏∞Îã§Î¶¨Í±∞ÎÇò, Ïïà ÏÇ¨Í≤†Îã§Í≥† ÌïòÎäî Ïû†Ïû¨ Í≥†Í∞ùÏÇ¨ ÎåÄÌëúÏùò ÏÉàÎ≤Ω Ï∂úÍ∑ºÍ∏∏ ÏûêÍ∞ÄÏö©Ïùò Î¨∏ÏùÑ Í∏∞ÏÇ¨Îãò ÎåÄÏã† Îß§Ïùº Ïó¥Ïñ¥Ï£ºÍ≥† Ïù∏ÏÇ¨ÌïòÎäî ÏßìÏùÑ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Ï¶êÍ≤ÅÍ≥† Í∏∞ÏÅòÍ≤å ÌïòÏßÑ ÏïäÏùÑ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïù¥Îì§ÏóêÍ≤åÎèÑ ÏïÑÏ£º Ï∞ΩÌîºÌïòÍ≥†, ÏûêÏ°¥Ïã¨ ÏÉÅÌïòÍ≥†, ÌïòÍ∏∞ Ïã´ÏùÄ ÏùºÏù¥ÏßÄÎßå, Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎãàÍπå ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.
Î™®Îì† Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏóêÍ≤ê Ïñ¥Îäê Ï†ïÎèÑÏùò Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÍ∞Ä Íº≠ ÌïÑÏöîÌïòÎã§Í≥† ÎÇòÎäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º Ï≤òÏùå Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïòÍ≥†, ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä Ïñ¥Îäê Ï†ïÎèÑ Í∂§ÎèÑÏóê Ïò¨ÎùºÍ∞ÄÍ∏∞ Ï†ÑÍπåÏßÄÎäî ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÎì§Ïù¥ ÎßåÎÇòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ±∞ÎÇò Í¥ÄÏã¨ ÏóÜÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥Í≥†, ÌòëÎ†•ÏóÖÏ≤¥Îì§Ïù¥ ÌòëÏóÖÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ±∞ÎÇò Í¥ÄÏã¨ ÏóÜÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥Í≥†, Ï¢ãÏùÄ Ïû†Ïû¨ ÏûÑÏßÅÏõêÎ∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ ÎßåÎÇòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ±∞ÎÇò Í¥ÄÏã¨ ÏóÜÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù∏Îç∞, ÎÇòÎ•º ÎßåÎÇòÍ∏∞ Ïã´Í±∞ÎÇò ÎÇòÏóêÍ≤å Í¥ÄÏã¨Ïù¥ ÏóÜÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÍ≥º ÎßåÎÇòÏÑú Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ïú†ÏùºÌïú Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÄ Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÏñºÍµ¥Ïóê Ï≤†Ìåê ÍπîÍ≥† Ï≥êÎì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. ÏïÑÏ£º ÌûòÎì§Í≥†, ÏïÑÏ£º Ï™ΩÌåîÎ¶¨Í≥†, ÏïÑÏ£º ÏûêÏ°¥Ïã¨ ÏÉÅÌïòÍ≥†, Íµ≥Ïù¥ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤åÍπåÏßÄ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎÇò ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏù¥ ÎìúÎäî, Í∑∏Îü∞ ÌñâÎèôÏù¥ÏßÄÎßå, ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑúÎäî ÌïÑÏöîÌïú ÏùºÏù¥Îã§. ÏôúÎÉêÌïòÎ©¥, Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Î¨¥Î¶¨ÏàòÎ•º Îë¨ÏÑú ÏùºÎã® ÎßåÎÇòÎ©¥ Í∑∏ Ïù¥ÌõÑÏóê Ïïà Îê† ÏùºÎèÑ ÎêòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎÇòÎäî ÏßÅÏ†ë Í≤ΩÌóòÌï¥Î¥§Í≥†, Ïó¨Îü¨ Î≤à ÏòÜÏóêÏÑú Î™©Í≤©ÌñàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.
Îã§Ïãú ÌïúÎ≤à Í∞ïÏ°∞ÌïúÎã§. Í∑∏ ÎàÑÍµ¨ÎèÑ Ï≤†Î©¥ÌîºÎ•º Í∞ñÍ≥† ÌÉúÏñ¥ÎÇòÏßÑ ÏïäÏïòÎã§. Íº≠ ÌïÑÏöîÌïòÍ≥†, Íº≠ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎãàÍπå ÎÇØÏßùÏùÑ ÎëêÍªçÍ≤å ÎßåÎì† Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.

ÎÇòÎäî Í∞úÏù∏Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎ•º Ï¢ãÏïÑÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïòÎäî Í±∏ Ï†ÅÍ∑πÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ï∂îÏ≤úÌïòÍ≥† ÏùëÏõêÌïúÎã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏóêÍ≤åÎßå Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò Ïù¥Îì§ÏóêÍ≤åÎßå Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÎäî ÌéÄÎìúÍ∞Ä ÏûàÎäî Í±¥ ÏïÑÎãàÏßÄÎßå, Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±ÏùÄ ÏßÄÍ∏àÍπåÏßÄ Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌûà ÎåÄÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌåÄÏóê Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÍ≥† Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ ÌïòÎäî Î™á Í∞úÏùò Ïù¥Î≤§Ìä∏Î•º ÌõÑÏõêÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïö∞Î¶∞ Î™®Îëê Îã§ Î∞îÎπ†ÏÑú Ïô∏Î∂Ä Í∞ïÏó∞Ïù¥ÎÇò Î∞úÌëúÎäî Í±∞Ïùò Ïïà, Î™ª ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, ÌïôÏÉùÎì§ ÎåÄÏÉÅÏùò Í∞ïÏó∞Ïù¥ÎÇò Î∞úÌëú, ÎòêÎäî Ìï¥Ïª§ÌÜ§ Ïã¨ÏÇ¨Îäî Ïõ¨ÎßåÌïòÎ©¥ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÏÑú Ï∞∏ÏÑùÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïùò ÎÇòÏù¥Îäî Ï†êÏ†ê Îçî ÎÇÆÏïÑÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÏßÄÌñ•ÌïòÎäî Ï≤´ Î≤àÏß∏ Í∏∞Í¥ÄÌà¨ÏûêÏûêÍ∞Ä ÎêòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑúÎäî Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî ÌïôÏÉùÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å Ìà¨ÏûêÌï¥Ïïº ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. Í≤∞Íµ≠ Ïù¥ ÌïôÏÉùÎì§ÏùÄ Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±Ïùò ÎØ∏ÎûòÏùò Í≥†Í∞ùÏù¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÌïôÏÉùÎì§ ÎåÄÏÉÅÏúºÎ°ú ÌïòÎäî Î™®Îì† ÌôúÎèôÏùÄ Ïû†Ïû¨ Í≥†Í∞ùÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏòÅÏóÖ/ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖ ÌôúÎèôÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† Î¥êÎèÑ Î¨¥Î∞©ÌïòÎã§. Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ ÏßÄÍ∏à ÎòêÎäî ÎÇòÏ§ëÏóê Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌï† Îïå, Í∞ÄÏû• Î®ºÏ†Ä ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÎÇòÎäî VCÍ∞Ä Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±Î≤§Ï≤òÏä§Í∞Ä ÎêòÎäî Í≤å Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Î™©ÌëúÎã§.
ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±ÏùÑ ÏãúÏûëÌïú 2012ÎÖÑÎßå Ìï¥ÎèÑ ÌïôÏÉùÎì§ÏùÄ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÏùÑ Í±∞Ïùò ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§. Ï∞ΩÏóÖÏù¥ Î≠îÏßÄÎèÑ Î™∞ÎûêÍ≥†, Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÌïòÎäîÏßÄÎèÑ Î™∞ÎûêÍ≥†, Ïù¥Îì§ÏóêÍ≤å Ìà¨ÏûêÌï¥ Ï£ºÎäî VCÎèÑ ÏóÜÏóàÎã§. Ï∞ΩÏóÖÏùÄ Ï∑®ÏóÖÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÎ©¥ Ïñ¥Ï©î Ïàò ÏóÜÏù¥ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ ÏòµÏÖòÏù¥ÏóàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎãπÏãúÏóê ÎßåÎÇ¨Îçò ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÄ Ï§ÄÎπÑÎèÑ Ïïà ÎêêÍ≥†, Ïã§Î†•ÎèÑ ÏóÜÏóàÎã§. Ïã§ÏùÄ, ÏïÑÏßÅÎèÑ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò ÌïôÎ∂ÄÏÉùÏù¥ÎÇò ÎåÄÌïôÏõêÏÉùÎì§ÏùÄ Ï∑®ÏóÖÏùÑ ÏÑ†Ìò∏ÌïòÍ∏¥ ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, ÏöîÏÉå Ï∞ΩÏóÖÏùÑ 1ÏàúÏúÑÎ°ú ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎäî ÌïôÏÉùÎì§Ïù¥ Ï†êÏ†ê Îçî ÎßéÏïÑÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í≤å ÎÇ¥ Í∞úÏù∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏù¥Îã§.
ÏöîÏÉàÎèÑ Ïö∞Î¶∞ Îçî ÎßéÏùÄ ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎ•º ÎßåÎÇòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú Î∞©Î≤ïÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Í≥†ÎØºÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, ÌòπÏãú Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÏùΩÎäî ÌïôÏÉùÎ∂ÑÎì§ Ï§ë Ï¢ãÏùÄ Î∞©Î≤ïÏù¥ ÏûàÎã§Î©¥ Ïñ∏Ï†úÎì†ÏßÄ Ï†úÏïàÌï¥ Ï£ºÏãúÎ©¥ Ï¢ãÍ≤†Îã§.
Ïù¥ÎØ∏ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌñàÍ±∞ÎÇò, Ï∞ΩÏóÖÏùÑ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎäî ÌïôÏÉùÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Î™á Í∞ÄÏßÄ Ìï¥Ï£ºÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Ï°∞Ïñ∏Ïù¥ ÏûàÎã§. Íº≠ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÌïòÎùºÎäî Í±¥ ÏïÑÎãàÏßÄÎßå, Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïòÍ∏∞ Ï†ÑÏóê Ï∂©Î∂ÑÌûà ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥ Î¥êÏïº ÌïòÎäî Ï£ºÏ†úÎì§Ïù¥Í≥†, Î™á Í∞úÎäî ÎÇòÏ§ëÏóê ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÏºúÏ°åÏùÑ Îïå Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà ÎßùÍ∞ÄÎú®Î¶¥ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ï§ëÏöîÌïú ÎÇ¥Ïö©Ïù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§.
ÏùºÎã® Í∞ÄÏû• Ï≤´ Î≤àÏß∏ Ï°∞Ïñ∏ÏùÄ, ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÄ ÌïôÍµê Í≥ºÏ†úÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎßåÎÇòÎäî ÎßéÏùÄ ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎäî Ïã§ÏùÄ ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÎùº Í∑∏ÎÉ• Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Í≥ºÏ†úÎ•º ÌïòÎäî ÌïôÏÉùÏù¥Îã§. Ïù¥Îì§ÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÌï† Ï§ÄÎπÑÍ∞Ä Ï†ÑÌòÄ ÎêòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÍ≥†, Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÌïôÏóÖ Ïô∏ Ïû¨ÎØ∏ÏûàÎäî ÏùºÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂Í≥†, Î©ÄÎ¶¨ÏÑú Îã§Î•∏ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎ•º Î≥¥ÎãàÍπå Î≥∏Ïù∏Îì§ÎèÑ Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑ Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§Îäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î≤ïÏù∏ÏÑ§Î¶ΩÌïòÍ≥† ÎåÄÌëúÏù¥ÏÇ¨ Î™ÖÌï® ÎßåÎì§Í≥†, ÏΩîÌååÏö¥Îçî Î™ÖÌï® ÎßåÎì§Î©¥ÏÑú Ïó¨Í∏∞Ï†ÄÍ∏∞ Í∏∞ÏõÉÍ±∞Î¶¨Îäî ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùò ÌôúÎèôÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Ïñ¥Îñ§ Î∂ÑÏùÄ ÏÜåÏúÑ ÎßêÌïòÎäî Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖ ÎåÄÌëúÏù¥ÏÇ¨ ÎÜÄÏù¥Ïóê Îπ†Ï†∏ÏûàÍ≥†, Ï°∏ÏóÖÌïòÍ≥† ÎåÄÍ∏∞ÏóÖÏóê Ï∑®ÏßÅÌïòÎäî Í≤å Î™©Ï†ÅÏù∏Îç∞, Ïù¥Î†•ÏÑúÏóê ‚ÄúABC Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Í≤ΩÌóò‚Äù Ìïú Ï§Ñ Îã¨Í∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑú Ï∞ΩÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ÎèÑ ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÌïòÎã§ Î≥¥Îãà, ÎãπÏó∞Ìûà ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌíÄÌÉÄÏûÑÏúºÎ°ú Ïïà ÌïúÎã§. ÌïôÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ Î≥ëÌñâÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎåÄÏ∂©ÎåÄÏ∂©, Í±¥ÏÑ±Í±¥ÏÑ± Ìï¥ÏÑú Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Îêú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Î©¥, Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä 14ÎÖÑ ÎèôÏïà Ìà¨ÏûêÌïú 290Í∞úÏùò ÌöåÏÇ¨Îäî Î™®Îëê Îã§ Ïú†ÎãàÏΩòÏù¥ ÎèºÏïº ÌñàÎã§.
Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏóêÍ≤å Í∞ÄÏû• Î®ºÏ†Ä ÎìúÎ¶¨Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Ï°∞Ïñ∏ÏùÄ, Ï†ïÎßêÎ°ú Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎ†§Î©¥ ÏùºÎã® Í∑∏ ÎßàÏùåÍ∞ÄÏßêÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥†, Ïù¥Î•º Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú ÌñâÎèôÏóê ÏòÆÍ∏∞Î†§Î©¥ ÌïôÏóÖÏùÑ Ìú¥ÌïôÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò, ÏïÑÎãàÎ©¥ ÏûêÌá¥ÌïòÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥†ÏÑúÎäî Ï†àÎåÄÎ°ú Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ Ìï† ÏàòÍ∞Ä ÏóÜÎã§. ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Ïù¥ÏßÑÎ≤ïÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏÉùÍ∞Å Í∞ôÏßÄÎßå, Ï∞ΩÏóÖÏùÄ all in or nothingÏù¥Îã§.
Îëê Î≤àÏß∏ Ï°∞Ïñ∏ÏùÄ, ÍµêÏàòÎãòÏùò ÎßêÏùÑ ÎßπÏã†ÌïòÏßÄ ÎßêÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÎêòÎèÑÎ°ù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïòÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Ï£ºÏ£ºÎ™ÖÎ∂ÄÏóêÏÑú ÍµêÏàòÎãòÏùÄ ÎπºÍ±∞ÎÇò, ÏïÑÎãàÎ©¥ Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò ÏßÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ 2% Ïù¥ÌïòÎ°ú ÎÇÆÏ∂îÎùºÎäî Ï°∞Ïñ∏ÏùÑ ÎìúÎ¶¨Í≥† Ïã∂Îã§. ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎßåÎÇòÎäî ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖ Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖÏùÄ, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÌäπÌûà ÏßÄÎèÑÍµêÏàòÍ∞Ä ÏûàÎäî ÎåÄÌïôÏõêÏÉùÏù¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïú Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖÏùò Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌåÄÏóêÎäî ÏßÄÎèÑÍµêÏàòÍ∞Ä Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞Ä ÏûàÎã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò Í≤ΩÏö∞ Ïù¥Îì§ÏùÄ 30% Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùò ÏßÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïú†ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Ïù¥Í≤å Ïôú ÌãÄÎ†∏ÎäîÏßÄÎäî ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ï†ÑÏóê Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑú ÎåÄÎûµ ÏÑ§Î™ÖÌñàÎäîÎç∞, Îã§Ïãú ÌïúÎ≤à Í∞ÑÎûµÌïòÍ≤å ÏöîÏïΩÌïòÏûêÎ©¥, Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖÏùò ÏΩîÌååÏö¥ÎçîÎäî 1ÎÖÑ 365Ïùº ÌïòÎ£® 24ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Ïù¥ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÎßå Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏóê Í∑∏ Î¨¥ÏóáÎ≥¥Îã§ ÎÜíÏùÄ Ïö∞ÏÑ†ÏàúÏúÑÎ•º Îë¨Ïïº ÌïúÎã§. ÍµêÏàòÎì§ÏùÄ Ïù¥Í≤å Íµ¨Ï°∞Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ïïà ÎêúÎã§. ÏôúÎÉêÌïòÎ©¥ ÌïôÍµêÍ∞Ä Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò ÏßÅÏû•Ïù¥ÎùºÏÑú Ìï≠ÏÉÅ ÌïôÍµêÍ∞Ä Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò Ïö∞ÏÑ†ÏàúÏúÑÏù¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. ÎÇòÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä Ïûò ÎêòÎ©¥ Í∞ÄÏû• Í≥†ÏÉùÌïòÍ≥† Í∏∞Ïó¨Î•º ÎßéÏù¥ Ìïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• ÎßéÏùÄ ÎèàÏùÑ Î≤åÏñ¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎäîÎç∞ ÏßÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥ Ïù¥Í±∏ Í≤∞Ï†ïÌïúÎã§. ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä Ïïà ÎêòÎ©¥ Ïó≠Ïãú ÏßÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Ï±ÖÏûÑÍ≥º ÎπÑÎÇúÏùÑ Î∞õÏïÑÏïº ÌïúÎã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê all in ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥†, ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÎÇ† ÎïåÎßàÎã§ ÏôÄÏÑú ÌååÌä∏ÌÉÄÏûÑÏúºÎ°ú Ï°∞Ïñ∏Í≥º ÌõàÏàòÎ•º ÌïòÎäî ÍµêÏàòÎì§Ïù¥ ÏßÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎßéÏù¥ Î≥¥Ïú†ÌïòÎäî Í±¥ ÌôïÏã§Ìûà Î∂àÍ≥µÌèâÌïòÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÍµêÏàòÎì§ÏùÄ ÌïôÍµêÏóêÏÑú Í∞ÄÎ•¥ÏπòÍ≥†, Î≥∏Ïù∏Ïù¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÏûàÍ≥†, ÏßÄÎèÑÌïòÎäî ÌïôÏÉùÎì§Ïù¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌïú 3~4Í∞ú ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò ÎÜíÏùÄ ÏßÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïú†Ìïú C Î†àÎ≤® ÏûÑÏõêÏúºÎ°ú ÌôúÎèôÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥Îü∞ Íµ¨Ï°∞Î°ú ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÎÇòÏ§ëÏóê Ìà¨ÏûêÎ∞õÍ≥†, Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏùÑ Ï±ÑÏö©ÌïòÍ≥†, Ïûò ÎêòÎäî Í±¥ ÏâΩÏßÄ ÏïäÎã§.
Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú ÎêòÎèÑÎ°ù ÍµêÏàòÎäî Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌåÄÏóêÏÑú ÎπºÎùº. Íº≠ Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò Ï°∞Ïñ∏Ïù¥ÎÇò ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÌïÑÏöîÌïòÎã§Î©¥ Ïä§ÌÜ°ÏòµÏÖòÏùÑ 0.5% Ïù¥ÌïòÎ°ú Ï£ºÍ≥† Í≥†Î¨∏ÏúºÎ°ú Î™®ÏãúÎäî Í±∏ Í∂åÏû•ÌïúÎã§. Ï†ÑÏóê Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÌïôÏÉù ÎåÄÌëúÏóêÍ≤å Ïù¥Îü∞ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º ÌïòÎãàÍπå ÍµâÏû•Ìûà Í≥§ÎûÄÌï¥ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÎÇòÏóêÍ≤å Îã§ÏùåÍ≥º Í∞ôÏùÄ ÎßêÏùÑ ÌñàÎã§. Î≥∏Ïù∏ÎèÑ Ï°∏ÏóÖÌï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ÏßÄÎèÑÍµêÏàòÎãòÏù¥ ÏäπÏù∏ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏúºÎ©¥ Ï°∏ÏóÖÏùÑ Î™ª ÌïòÎØÄÎ°ú Ïù¥Îü∞ ÍªÑÎÅÑÎü¨Ïö¥ ÎåÄÌôîÎ•º ÌïòÎäî Í≤å ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÌûòÎì§Îã§Í≥†. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏúÑÏóêÏÑú ÎßêÌïú ÎåÄÎ°ú ÏßÑÏßúÎ°ú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎ†§Î©¥ Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÌïôÏóÖÏùÑ Ï§ëÎã®ÌïòÎäî Í≤å Ïù¥Îü∞ Ï°∏ÏóÖÏùò Í≥†ÎØºÏúºÎ°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏûêÏú†Î°úÏõåÏßà Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Í∞ÄÏû• Ï¢ãÏùÄ Î∞©Î≤ïÏù¥Îã§. ÏïÑÎãàÎ©¥, ÍµêÏàòÎãòÍ≥º Ïù¥ ÌûòÎì† ÎåÄÌôîÎ•º Ìï¥ÏÑú ÏáºÎ∂ÄÎ•º Î¥êÏïº ÌïúÎã§. ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÌïòÎ©¥ Ïù¥Î≥¥Îã§ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îçî Ïñ¥Î†§Ïö¥ ÎåÄÌôîÎ•º ÎßéÏù¥ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÍ≥† Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îçî ÌûòÎì† Í≤∞Ï†ïÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑúÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÎßâÌûåÎã§Î©¥ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖ Î™ª ÌïúÎã§.
ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ Ï°∞Ïñ∏ÏùÄ, Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖÏùÄ ÎèàÏùÑ Î≤ÑÎäî ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÎßåÎìúÎäî Í≥≥Ïù¥ÏßÄ, Í∑∏ ÎàÑÍµ¨ÎèÑ Îî∞Îùº Ìï† Ïàò ÏóÜÎäî Í∏∞Ïà†ÏùÑ Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÎäî Ï°∞ÏßÅÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùºÎäî Ï†êÏù¥Îã§. Î≥∏Ïù∏Ïù¥ ÌòÑÏû¨ Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÍ≥† Ïó∞Íµ¨ÌïòÎäî Î∂ÑÏïºÍ∞Ä ÏÑ∏Í≥Ñ ÏµúÍ≥† ÏàòÏ§ÄÏù¥ÎùºÎ©¥ Ïù¥Í±¥ Ï†ïÎßê ÎåÄÎã®ÌïòÍ≥† Ï∂ïÌïòÌï†ÎßåÌïòÎã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Í∑∏Î†áÎã§Í≥† Ïù¥Í≤å ÏÑ∏Í≥Ñ ÏµúÍ≥†Ïùò ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏù¥ ÎêúÎã§Îäî Î≥¥Ïû•ÏùÄ ÏóÜÎã§. ÏïÑÎãà, Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å ÎêòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Îäî Í±∞Ïùò ÏóÜÎã§. Í∑∏Îüº, ÎÖ∏Î≤®ÏÉÅ Î∞õÏùÄ Î™®Îì† Ïù¥Î°†Í≥º Í∏∞Ïà†Ïù¥ Ïú†ÎãàÏΩò ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏù¥ ÎèºÏïº ÌïúÎã§. Í∏∞Ïà†ÏùÄ Í∑∏ÎÉ• Îã®ÏßÄ Í∏∞Ïà†Ïùº ÎøêÏù¥Îã§. Ïù¥ Í∏∞Ïà†ÏùÑ Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú ÎπÑÏ¶àÎãàÏä§ Î™®Îç∏ÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Í≥†, Îçî ÎÇòÏïÑÍ∞ÄÏÑúÎäî ÎèàÏùÑ Î≤ÑÎäî ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏúºÎ°ú ÏßÑÌôîÏãúÌÇ§Îäî Í±¥ ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà Îã§Î•∏ ÏùºÏù¥Îã§. Ïó∞Íµ¨Î≥¥Îã§ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏù¥ Îçî Ïñ¥Î†µÎã§Îäî ÎßêÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà Îã§Î•¥Îã§Îäî ÎßêÏù¥Îã§.
Ïö∞Î¶¨ Í∞ôÏùÄ VCÎäî Í∏∞Ïà†Ïóê Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäîÎã§. Í∑∏ Í∏∞Ïà†Î°ú ÎßåÎìúÎäî ÎèàÏùÑ Î≤ÑÎäî ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏóê Ìà¨ÏûêÌïúÎã§. Ïù¥Í±∏ Î™ÖÌôïÌïòÍ≤å Ïù¥Ìï¥Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§. 
ÎÇòÎäî Ï†äÍ≥†, ÎòëÎòëÌïòÍ≥†, ÏóêÎÑàÏßÄ ÎÑòÏπòÎäî ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎ•º Ï†ïÎßê Ï¢ãÏïÑÌïúÎã§. Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ ÎßòÎ®πÍ≥† ÏÇ¨Í≥† ÏπòÎ©¥ Ïú†ÎãàÏΩòÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùº Îç∞Ïπ¥ÏΩò Î™á ÎßàÎ¶¨ ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Í≥† ÎØøÎäîÎã§. ÎÇòÎäî Îçî ÎßéÏùÄ ÌïôÏÉùÏù¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÌï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. ÌäπÌûà, ÏúÑÏóêÏÑú ÎßêÌïú ÎÇ¥Ïö©Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Ï∂©Î∂ÑÌûà Í≥†ÎØºÌï¥ Î≥∏ ÌïôÏÉù Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ÎùºÎ©¥ Ïñ∏Ï†úÎì†ÏßÄ Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±Ïóê Ïó∞ÎùΩÌï¥ Ï£ºÏãúÍ∏∏.

ÌíçÎÖÑÏù¥Î©¥ ÏåÄÍ∞íÏù¥ Ïã∏Ï†∏ÏÑú ÎèàÏùÑ Î™ªÎ≤åÍ≥†, ÌùâÎÖÑÏù¥Î©¥ ÎÇ¥Îã§ Ìåî ÏåÄÏù¥ ÏóÜÏñ¥ÏÑú ÎèàÏùÑ Î™ªÎ≤åÏóàÎã§. Ï°∞ÏÑ† ÌõÑÍ∏∞ ÎØºÏ§ëÎì§Ïùò ÏÇ∂ÏùÄ ÌåçÌåçÌïòÍ∏∞ Í∑∏ÏßÄÏóÜÏóàÎã§. Ïò§ÎäòÎÇ† Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÎåÄÏ∂ú Ïù¥ÏûêÏóê ÏãúÎã¨Î¶¨ÎìØ Í∑∏ÎïåÏùò ÎØºÏ§ëÎì§ÏùÄ ÎèôÎÑ§ ÏñëÎ∞òÏßÄÏ£ºÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å ÎïÖÍ≥º ÏåÄÏùÑ ÎπåÎ†∏Îã§. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Ïù¥Í≤å Î¨∏Ï†úÏòÄÎã§. ÎπÑÏú®Ï†úÏòÄÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÏåÄ 100ÏÑùÏùÑ ÏÉùÏÇ∞ÌïòÎ©¥ 50ÏÑù, 150ÏÑùÏùÑ ÏÉùÏÇ∞ÌïòÎ©¥ 75ÏÑùÏùÑ ÎÇ¥ÏïºÌïòÎäî ÏãùÏù¥ÏóàÎã§. ÏãùÎüâÏù¥ Î∂ÄÏ°±Ìïú Î¥ÑÏ≤†, Ïù¥Î•∏Î∞î Ï∂òÍ∂ÅÍ∏∞Ïóê ÏåÄÏùÑ ÎπåÎ¶¨Î©¥ ÎòêÎã§Ïãú 50%Ïùò Ïù¥ÏûêÍ∞Ä Î∂ôÏóàÎã§. Í∑∏ Í≤∞Í≥º Ï∂îÏàò ÎïåÍ∞Ä ÎêòÎ©¥ ÏÉùÏÇ∞ÎüâÏùò 60~80%Î•º Ïù¥ÏûêÎ°ú ÎÇ¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ÎèÑ Ï†ÅÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§. ÏûÑÏà†ÎÜçÎØºÎ¥âÍ∏∞(1862), ÎèôÌïôÎÜçÎØºÏö¥Îèô(1894) Îì± Íµ¨ÌïúÎßê ÎÜçÎØºÎì§Ïùò Ï†ÄÌï≠Ïù¥ Í≥ÑÏÜçÎêú Ïù¥Ïú†ÎèÑ Í≤∞Íµ≠ÏùÄ Î¨¥ÏûêÎπÑÌïú Ïù¥Ïûê ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥ÏóàÎã§.
ÏÜåÏûë Î¨∏Ï†úÎäî ÏùºÏ†úÍ∞ïÏ†êÍ∏∞ Îì§Ïñ¥ ÎçîÏö± ÏïÖÌôîÎêòÏóàÎã§. Ï†úÍµ≠Ï£ºÏùò Î≥∏Íµ≠ÏóêÏÑú ÏãùÎØºÏßÄ Î∞±ÏÑ±Îì§Ïùò Í≥†ÌÜµÏóê Î¨¥Ïä® Í¥ÄÏã¨Ïù¥ ÏûàÍ≤†ÎäîÍ∞Ä. ÏàúÏÇ¨Îì§ÏùÄ Î™®Î•∏ Ï≤ôÏúºÎ°ú ÏùºÍ¥ÄÌñàÍ≥† Ï¥ùÎèÖÎ∂ÄÎäî ÏßÄÏ£º Ìé∏Ïù¥ÏóàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎÜçÎØºÏùÄ ÏÜåÏûëÍ∂åÎßàÏ†Ä Î≥¥Ïû•Î∞õÏßÄ Î™ªÌñàÎã§. ÏÜåÏÑ§ „ÄäÏÇ¨ÌïòÏ¥å„ÄãÏóêÏÑúÎäî Í∞ëÏûêÍ∏∞ ÏÜåÏûëÍ∂åÏùÑ ÎπºÏïóÍ≤®ÏÑú Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄÏùÑ Í≤™Í≤å ÎêòÎäî ÎÜçÎØº Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏúÑÏóê ÎÇòÏò® Í≤ÉÏ≤òÎüº ÎπöÏùÑ Í∞êÎãπÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÎã§ ÏûêÏã†Ïùò ÎïÖÎßàÏ†Ä ÎπºÏïóÍ∏∞Îäî Ïò®Í∞ñ ÎπÑÍ∑πÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Îã¥Í≤®ÏûàÎã§.
Ïù¥ÏûêÎäî ÏãúÎåÄÎßàÎã§ Îã§Î•∏ Ïù¥Î¶ÑÏúºÎ°ú Î∂àÎ†§ ÏôîÏßÄÎßå, Í∑∏ Ïó≠ÏÇ¨Îäî Ïò§ÎûòÎêêÎã§. ‚ÄòÎèàÎÜÄÏù¥‚ÄôÎÇò ‚ÄòÏÇ¨Ï±Ñ‚Äô Í∞ôÏùÄ ÌëúÌòÑÏù¥ ÎßêÌï¥Ï£ºÎìØ, ÎèàÏùÑ ÎπåÎ†§Ï£ºÍ≥† Ïù¥ÏûêÎ•º Î∞õÎäî ÌñâÏúÑÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Í≤ΩÍ≥ÑÏôÄ Î∂àÏã†ÏùÄ Í≥†ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï°¥Ïû¨Ìï¥ÏôîÎã§. ÎèàÏù¥ÎÇò ÎïÖÏùÑ ÎπåÎ†§Ï£ºÏñ¥ Ïù¥ÏùµÏùÑ ÏñªÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ ÏÉùÍ≤®ÎÇ¨Í≥†, Ïù¥ÏûêÎ•º Í∞êÎãπÌïòÎ©∞ ÏÉùÍ≥ÑÎ•º Ïù¥Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÎäî Î∞©Ïãù Ïó≠Ïãú ÏãúÎåÄÏôÄ ÏßÄÏó≠ÏùÑ Í∞ÄÎ¶¨ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† Î∞òÎ≥µÎêêÎã§.
ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Í∑ºÎåÄ ÏÇ∞ÏóÖÌòÅÎ™ÖÏùÑ Í±∞ÏπòÎ©∞ Ïù¥ÏûêÏùò ÏùòÎØ∏Îäî Îã¨ÎùºÏßÄÍ∏∞ ÏãúÏûëÌïúÎã§. Í∏àÏúµ Ï†úÎèÑÍ∞Ä Ï†ïÎπÑÎêòÍ≥† Í≤ΩÏ†úÎ•º Ïö¥ÏòÅÌïòÎäî Î∞©ÏãùÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Ïù¥Ìï¥Í∞Ä ÍπäÏñ¥ÏßÄÎ©¥ÏÑú, Ïù¥ÏûêÎäî Í∞úÏù∏ Í∞Ñ Í±∞ÎûòÎ•º ÎÑòÏñ¥ Î≥¥Îã§ Ï°∞ÏßÅÏ†ÅÏù¥Í≥† Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ Í≤ΩÏ†ú ÌôúÎèôÏùò ÏùºÎ∂ÄÎ°ú ÏûêÎ¶¨ Ïû°Í≤å ÎêúÎã§. Ïù¥ Î≥ÄÌôîÏùò ÌùêÎ¶Ñ ÏÜçÏóêÏÑú, Ïù¥ÏûêÎ•º Îã§Î£®Îäî Î∞©ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú ÏãúÎåÄÎ•º ÏïûÏÑúÍ∞Ñ ‚ÄòÏßÄÏïÑÎãàÎãà‚ÄôÎùºÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎã§.
Í∏∞Ìöå: Î±ÖÌÅ¨ Ïò§Î∏å ÏïÑÎ©îÎ¶¨Ïπ¥ÏôÄ Î∞±ÏÑ§Í≥µÏ£º

Ïû¨Î¨¥Î∂Ä Ïû•Í¥ÄÍ≥º Ï∞®Í¥ÄÏùò Ïó∞Ï§Ä Ï∞∏Ïó¨Î•º Ï†úÌïúÌïòÍ≥†, Ïó∞Ï§Ä Ïù¥ÏÇ¨Ïùò ÍµêÏ≤¥ Ï£ºÍ∏∞ÎèÑ Ï†ïÍ∂å ÍµêÏ≤¥Ïóê ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ Î∞õÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Î∞©ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú Ï°∞Ï†ïÌñàÏúºÎ©∞, ÎåÄÌÜµÎ†πÏùò ÏûÑÍ∏∞ ÎèôÏïà Ïó∞Ï§Ä ÏúÑÏõê ÏûÑÎ™ÖÏóê Ï†úÌïúÏùÑ ÎëêÏóàÎã§. Ïπ®Ïãù: ÎÇòÎùºÎ•º Îã¥Î≥¥Î°ú Ìïú ÎåÄÏ∂ú
Ï°∞ÏÑ† Îßê Íµ≠Í∞ÄÏùò Ïû¨Ï†ï ÏÉÅÌÉúÎäî ÏóâÎßùÏù¥ÏóàÎã§. ‚ÄòÎÇòÎùºÏóêÎäî Ìïú Îã¨ Ïì∏ ÎπÑÏ∂ïÎèÑ ÏóÜÎã§‚ÄôÎùºÎäî ÎßêÏù¥ ÎÇòÏò¨ ÏßÄÍ≤ΩÏù¥ÏóàÎã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ï≤†ÎèÑÎ•º ÎÜìÍ≥† Ï†ÑÏã†ÏùÑ Ïó∞Í≤∞ÌïòÎäî ÎåÄÎã®ÏúÑ ÏÇ∞ÏóÖÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑúÎäî ÎßâÎåÄÌïú ÏñëÏùò ÏûêÍ∏àÏù¥ ÌïÑÏöîÌñàÍ≥†, Ï°∞ÏÑ†ÏùÄ Í≤∞Ï†ïÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏûêÍ∏àÏù¥ Î∂ÄÏ°±ÌñàÎã§.
Ïù¥ ÏôÄÏ§ëÏóê 1882ÎÖÑ ÏûÑÏò§Íµ∞ÎûÄÏùÑ ÏßÑÏïïÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ Ï≤≠ÎÇòÎùº Íµ∞ÎåÄÍ∞Ä Ï°∞ÏÑ†Ïóê ÌååÍ≤¨ÎêêÍ≥†, Ïù¥Îïå Ï§ëÍµ≠Ïùò Ï†ïÏπòÏù∏ Ïù¥ÌôçÏû•ÏùÄ ÏûêÏã†Ïùò Ïã¨Î≥µÏù∏ ÏõêÏÑ∏Í∞ú(ÏúÑÏïàÏä§Ïπ¥Ïù¥)Î•º Ìï®Íªò Î≥¥ÎÇ∏Îã§. ÏõêÏÑ∏Í∞úÏùò Î™©ÌëúÎäî Î™ÖÌôïÌñàÎã§. ÎßâÎåÄÌïú ÏûêÍ∏àÏùÑ ÎåÄÏ∂úÌï¥Ï£ºÍ≥† Ï°∞ÏÑ†ÏùÑ Ï≤≠ÎÇòÎùºÏóê ÏòàÏÜçÏãúÌÇ¨ Í≤É. Ï†ïÏπòÎ†•ÏùÑ Í∑πÎåÄÌôîÌïòÏó¨ ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò Í∞ÑÏÑ≠ÏùÑ ÎøåÎ¶¨ÏπòÍ≥† Ï°∞ÏÑ†ÏùÑ ÏãùÎØºÏßÄÎ°ú ÎßåÎì§ Í≤É. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÏõêÏπôÌïòÏóê ÏõêÏÑ∏Í∞úÎäî Ï†ÅÍ∑πÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ï∞®Í¥Ä Ï†ïÏ±ÖÏùÑ Ï∂îÏßÑÌïòÏòÄÎã§.
1882ÎÖÑ 8Ïõî Ï°∞ÏÑ†ÏùÄ Ï≤≠ÎÇòÎùºÎ°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ 50Îßå ÎÉ•Ïùò ÎèàÏùÑ Ïó∞Ïù¥Ïûê 8Î¶¨(0.8%), Í±∞Ïπò 7ÎÖÑ ÏÉÅÌôò Ï°∞Í±¥ÏúºÎ°ú ÎπåÎ†∏Îã§. Í∞úÌôî Ï†ïÏ±ÖÏùÑ Ï∂îÏßÑÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÎπåÎ†§Ïò® ÎåÄÍ∑úÎ™® Ï∞®Í¥ÄÏù¥ÏóàÎã§. 1885ÎÖÑ 6ÏõîÏóêÎäî ‚ÄòÏùòÏ£ºÏ†ÑÏÑ† Ï°∞ÏïΩ‚ÄôÏùÑ Ï≤¥Í≤∞ÌñàÎäîÎç∞ Ï†ÑÏã† ÏãúÏÑ§ÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥ 5ÎÖÑ Í±∞Ïπò 20ÎÖÑ Í∏∞ÌïúÏúºÎ°ú 10Îßå ÎÉ•Ïùò Ï∞®Í¥ÄÏùÑ Îòê ÎπåÎ†∏Îã§. Ïù¥ Ï°∞ÏïΩÏùÄ ÌååÍ≤©Ï†ÅÏù¥ÏóàÎã§. Ïù¥ÏûêÎ•º Î∞õÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. ÎåÄÏã† Îß§ÎÖÑ 5,000ÎÉ•Ïî© Î¨¥Ïù¥Ïûê ÏÉÅÌôòÏùÑ ÌïòÎêò ÏÉÅÌôòÏù¥ Ïñ¥Î†§Ïö∏ Í≤ΩÏö∞ Ï†ÑÏÑ†Î∂ÄÏÑ§Í∂å Î∞è Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Í∂åÏùÑ Ï≤≠ÎÇòÎùºÍ∞Ä Í∞ñÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Ï°∞Í±¥ÏúºÎ°ú ÌñàÎã§. 1889ÎÖÑÏù¥ ÎêòÎ©¥ Ï°∞ÏÑ†Ïù¥ Ï≤≠ÎÇòÎùºÏóêÍ≤å ÎπåÎ¶∞ ÎèàÏù¥ 130Îßå ÎÉ•Ïóê Îã¨ÌñàÎã§.
ÎãπÏãú Ï°∞ÏÑ†ÏùÄ Í∞ëÏã†Ï†ïÎ≥Ä Îïå ÌîºÌï¥Î•º Ïù¥Ïú†Î°ú Î∞∞ÏÉÅÍ∏àÏùÑ ÏöîÍµ¨ÌñàÎçò ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò 5Îßå ÎÉ•ÏùÑ Í∞öÏßÄ Î™ªÌï¥ ÏÑ∏Ï∞ΩÏñëÌñâ* Í∞ôÏùÄ Ìï¥Ïô∏ Í∏∞ÏóÖÏúºÎ°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÎèàÏùÑ ÎπåÎ¶¨Í≥† ÏûàÏóàÎã§. *1884ÎÖÑ ÎèÖÏùº ÎßàÏù¥Ïñ¥ ÏÉÅÏÇ¨(Meyer ÂïÜÁ§æ)Ïùò Ï†úÎ¨ºÌè¨ ÏßÄÏ†êÏúºÎ°ú ÏÑ§Î¶ΩÎêú Î¨¥Ïó≠ÏÉÅÏÇ¨. Í∑ºÎåÄÌôî Ï†ïÏ±ÖÏùÑ Î™ÖÎ∂ÑÏúºÎ°ú ÎèÖÏùºÏÇ∞ Í∏∞Í≥ÑÏôÄ Í∏∞Ïà†Ïûê ÎèÑÏûÖÏùÑ Îã¥ÎãπÌïòÎ©∞ Í∞ÅÏ¢Ö Ïù¥Í∂åÏùÑ ÌôïÎ≥¥Ìïú Ï∞ΩÍµ¨ Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ ÌñàÎã§.
Ïù¥ ÏÇ¨Î°ÄÎäî 19-20ÏÑ∏Í∏∞ Ï†úÍµ≠Ï£ºÏùò Íµ≠Í∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ ÏïΩÏÜåÍµ≠ÏùÑ ÏßÄÎ∞∞Ìï¥Ïò® Ï†ÑÌòïÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î∞©ÏãùÏù¥Í∏∞ÎèÑ ÌïòÎã§. ÏûêÍ∏àÏóê ÏùòÏ°¥ÌïòÍ≤å Ìïú ÌõÑ, ÎπöÏùÄ Ï†êÏ∞® ÌÜµÏ†úÏôÄ Í∞ÑÏÑ≠ÏúºÎ°ú Ïù¥Ïñ¥Ï°åÎã§.
